242.01 COMPOSITION; COMPENSATION.
   The Department of Police of the City shall consist of a Director/Chief and
such other officers and personnel as determined from time to time by the
Council. Compensation shall be as determined from time to time by Council.
(Ord. 4667. Passed 7-13-94.)
242.013 GENERAL RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Department of Police shall be responsible for the protection of persons
and property within the City against crime, violence and traffic hazards.
(Ord. 4654. Passed 10-27-93.)
242.016 DIRECTOR/CHIEF.
   The Department of Police shall be headed by a Director/Chief who shall be
responsible to the City Manager for the performance of the functions of the
Department. The duties and responsibilities of the Director/Chief shall
include, but not be limited to the following:
   (a)   Maintain public order.
   (b)   Prevent crimes against persons and property.
   (c)   Enforce all criminal laws and ordinances.
   (d)   Detect and apprehend offenders and suspected persons.
   (e)   Maintain records and files of crimes and criminals.
   (f)   Operate facilities for the safekeeping of prisoners.
   (g)   Develop and conduct community relations and education programs.
   (h)   Operate and maintain the police radio and other Municipal radio and
emergency communication systems as may be assigned to the Department by the
City Manager.
   (i)   Maintain records and logs relating to radio and emergency
communications systems as are required by law.
   (j)   Develop and maintain formal and informal cooperative relationships for
mutual aid with other police and criminal justice system agencies at all levels
of government and with private security organizations.
   (k)   Provide for continuing police training.
   (l)   Enforce traffic control ordinances and the State Motor Vehicle Code.
(Ord. 4654. Passed 10-27-93.)
242.02 K-9 CORPS.
   (a)   Police officers assigned to the K-9 Corps have the responsibility of
feeding and caring for the police dogs and shall be paid a sum of seventy-five
dollars ($75.00) per month for this service. In the case of passive, non-
aggressive police dogs, such as those used solely for the detection of drugs,
explosives and accelerants, police officers shall be paid a sum of forty
dollars ($40.00) per month.
(Ord. 4808. Passed 7-22-98.)
   (b)   The Director of Finance is hereby authorized and directed to make
checks payable monthly to the designated police officers.
(Res. 7046. Passed 5-23-72.)
242.03 BURGLAR ALARM SERVICE.
   (a)   The City may provide, upon request, a burglar alarm service for all
businesses and commercial and financial establishments within the City.
   (b)   An application for such service shall be made with the Director/Chief
of the Department of Police.
   (c)   All subscribers, current and new, to the burglar alarm service,
connected directly to the Police Department or to an answering service calling
the Department, shall pay an installation fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00)
to the Director of Finance.
   (d)   An annual fee of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), payable in
advance, shall be charged to all subscribers, including telephone and answering
service connections, and shall be collected by the Director of Finance.
   (e)   All subscribers using telephone devices connected to the Department,
or an answering service calling the Department, and all new subscribers
thereto, shall, in addition to the charges set forth in subsections (c) and (d)
hereof, pay a one time fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) for Trac Taping their
emergency calls to the Department, payable to the Director of Finance.
(Ord. 4667. Passed 7-13-94.)
242.04 SERVICE OUTSIDE CITY.
   (a)   No contract shall be entered into for providing police protection
outside the corporate limits of the City unless Council approves the terms of
any such proposed agreement.
   (b)   It shall be clearly demonstrated, in writing, that the entire cost of
providing police service outside the corporate limits will be borne by those
receiving such police protection.
(Res. 7455. Passed 4-11-79.)
242.05 COMPLIANCE WITH MUNICIPAL POLICE OFFICERS' EDUCATION AND TRAINING
COMMISSION STANDARDS.
   While receiving funds from the Commonwealth pursuant to the Municipal Police
Officers' Education and Training Act, Act 120 of 1974, as amended, the City
shall adhere to the rules, regulations and training standards established by
the Municipal Police Officers' Education and Training Commission.
(Res. 7540. Passed 7-9-80.)
242.06 FEE FOR ACCIDENT REPORTS; DEPOSIT OF MONEYS.
   (a)   A fee shall be established by ordinance of City Council and amended
from time to time for each copy of a traffic incident report furnished to a
person who has a legitimate reason for requesting the report.
   (b)   The money collected under this section shall be deposited in the City
Treasury at frequent periods, at the convenience of the Director/Chief, but at
least once each month.
(Ord. 4389. Passed 9-10-86; Ord. 5353. Passed 5-31-23.)
242.07 POLICE SERVICE AGREEMENTS.
   (a)   If the services of the Police Department or any member thereof are
requested by a private business, individual or organization for traffic or
crowd control, which services would involve duties beyond the regularly
scheduled working period, such employment shall be permitted.
   (b)   The business, individual or organization shall enter into a police
service agreement with the City for the providing of such services.
   (c)   At all times police officers shall remain employees of the City.
   (d)   The police service agreement shall provide for the signature of the
requesting individual, business or organization and shall provide for the
payment of an hourly fee for the officer used and the police cruiser.
   (e)   The compensation shall be paid to the City at an overtime rate as
determined by the current contract existing between the City and the Fraternal
Order of Police Flood City Lodge 86.
   (f)   A police service agreement shall be prepared and executed by all
parties. The agreement which follows the text of this section shall be used for
all Police Service Agreements.
POLICE_SERVICE_AGREEMENT
[Click_here_to_view_form_in_PDF_format.]
(Ord. 4667. Passed 7-13-94.)
242.08 FALSE ALARMS.
   (a)   A fee shall be established by ordinance of City Council and amended
from time to time for Police Department responses to false electronic, alarm
service or notifier alarms, in excess of two such in any twelve-month calendar
year, except as provided in subsection (b) hereof.
   (b)   All Fire Department responses to false fire alarms shall be charged a
service fee established by ordinance of City Council and amended from time to
time. The cost of a residential false fire alarm shall be assessed after one
such false alarm in a twelve-month calendar year. False alarm fees for
commercial, non-profit, tax exempt, including the properties of the Johnstown
Housing Authority, shall be assessed after the third such false alarm in any
twelve-month calendar year.
   (c)   The City will not serve as intervenor in the case of disputes arising
between the alarm service provider and any other person regarding the delivery
of alarm service, the quality of the alarm system equipment or the maintenance
thereof.
   (d)   False alarms received during the first two weeks after a new alarm
installation, or
periods when such systems are under repair or malfunction, with notification to
the Fire Department by way of telephone or verbal contact, will not be counted
for the purposes of subsections (a), (b) and (c) hereof. Nothing herein
authorizes any person to deliberately cause an alarm signal to be initiated
without advance permission of the 911 Center and notification of either the
Police or Fire Department.
   (e)   Exempt from all such fees are the educational and recreation
facilities of the Greater Johnstown School District, the educational and
recreational facilities of the Bishop McCort and the satellite parochial
educational facilities within the City of Johnstown.
(Ord. 4706. Passed 12-21-94; Ord. 5021. Passed 7-9-08; Ord. 5064. Passed 3-24-
10; Ord. 5353. Passed 5-31-23.)

244.01 COMPOSITION; COMPENSATION.
   The Department of Fire of the City shall consist of a Director/Chief of Fire
and such other officers and personnel as determined from time to time by the
Council. Compensation shall be as determined from time to time by Council.
(Ord. 4667. Passed 7-13-94.)
244.013 GENERAL RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Department of Fire shall be responsible for the protection of persons
and property within the City against fire.
(Ord. 4654. Passed 10-27-93.)
244.016 DIRECTOR/CHIEF.
   The Department of Fire shall be headed by a Director/Chief who shall be
responsible to the City Manager for the performance of the functions of the
Department. The duties and responsibilities of the Director/Chief shall
include, but not be limited to, the following:
   (a)   Prevent and extinguish fires.
   (b)   Identify, remove and control fire hazards, potential explosions and
dangerous chemicals.
   (c)   Enforce laws, ordinances, rules and regulations relating to fires,
fire hazards and other hazards encountered in fighting fires.
   (d)   Maintain records relating to fires and fire hazards.
   (e)   Conduct investigations, in cooperation with appropriate police and
fire marshall authorities, into suspected crimes relating to fire.
   (f)   Provide for the custody, maintenance and repair of Fire Department
vehicles and equipment.
   (g)   Develop and conduct community relations and education programs.
   (h)   Operate and maintain the fire radio, fire alarm and other components
of the fire emergency communication system except to the extent that these
functions are performed by another department.
   (i)   Maintain records and logs relating to radio and the emergency
communication system as required by law.
   (j)   Maintain a fire training program.
   (k)   Develop preplanned contingency plans for fighting fires in specific
buildings and other places.
   (l)   Develop cooperative agreements for mutual aid among and between other
fire-fighting entities, ambulance and rescue services and the Johnstown Fire
Department.
   (m)   Rescue persons from hazardous places and prevent persons from entering
dangerous places and/or becoming engulfed in dangerous situations.
(Ord. 4654. Passed 10-27-93.)
244.02 APPOINTMENTS.
   The Director/Chief of Fire and the Assistant Fire Chiefs of the Department
of Fire shall be appointed by the City Manager. Other personnel in the
Department shall be appointed in accordance with the civil service laws of the
Commonwealth, regulating the qualifications, manner of appointment, promotion,
demotion and discharge of members of fire bureaus in cities of the third class.
(Ord. 4667. Passed 7-13-94.)
244.03 DISPOSITION OF FIRE INSURANCE PROCEEDS; DELINQUENT TAXES.
   (a)   The Director of Finance or his or her designee (hereinafter referred
to as the "Municipal Officer") is hereby appointed as the designated officer
who is authorized to carry out all responsibilities and duties of the City, as
provided herein.
   (b)   For purposes of this section, "fire loss" or "claim for fire damage"
means any loss occurring after the effective date of this section and covered
under a policy of fire insurance, including any endorsements or riders to the
policy.
   (c)   No insurance company, association or exchange (hereinafter referred to
as the "insurer") doing business in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania shall pay
a claim of a named insured for fire damage to a structure located within the
City, where the amount recoverable for the fire loss to the structure under all
policies exceeds seven thousand, five hundred dollars ($7,500), unless the
insurer and the named insured comply with the provisions of Section 508(b) of
the Act of May 17, 1921 (P.L. 682, No. 284), as amended, and the provisions of
this section.
   (d)   The Municipal Officer shall, upon the written request of the named
insured, specifying the tax description of the property, the name and address
of the insurer and the date agreed upon by the insurer and the named insured as
the date of the receipt of a loss report of the claim, furnish the insurer with
either of the following within fourteen working days of the request:
      (1)   A certificate, or, at the discretion of the City, a verbal
notification, which shall be confirmed in writing by the insurer, to the effect
that, as of the date specified in the request, there are no delinquent taxes,
assessments, penalties or user charges against the property and that, as of the
date of the Municipal Officer's certificate or verbal notification, the City
has not certified any amount as the total cost incurred by the City for the
removal, repair or securing of a building or other structure on the property;
or
      (2)   A certificate and bill showing the amount of delinquent taxes,
assessments, penalties and user charges against the property, as of the date
specified in the request, that have not been paid as of the date of the
certificate, the amount of the total costs, if any, certified to the Municipal
Officer, that have been incurred by the City for the removal, repair or
securing of a building or other structure on the property. For the purposes of
this paragraph, the City shall provide to the Municipal Officer the total
amount, if any, of such costs, if available, or the amount of costs known to
the City at the time of the Municipal Officer's certificate.
   A tax assessment, penalty or user charge becomes delinquent at the time and
on the date a lien could otherwise have been filed against the property by the
City under applicable law.
   (e)   Upon the receipt of a certificate pursuant to paragraph (d)(1) hereof,
the insurer shall pay the claim of the named insured in accordance with the
policy terms.
   (f)   Upon the receipt of a certificate and bill pursuant to paragraph (d)
(2) hereof, the insurer shall return the bill to the Municipal Officer and
transfer to the Municipal Officer an amount from the insurance proceeds
necessary to pay the taxes, assessments, penalties, charges and costs as shown
on the bill, or the full amount of the insurance proceeds, whichever is the
lesser amount. The City shall receive the amount and apply or credit it to
payment of the items shown in the bill.
   (g)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the ability of the
City to recover any deficiency.
   (h)   The transfer of proceeds to the Municipal Officer shall be on a pro
rata basis by all insurers with applicable policies of insurance providing
protection for fire loss.
   (i)   The City may, by resolution, adopt additional procedures and
regulations to implement Section 508 of the Act of May 17, 1921 (P.L. 682, No.
284), as amended, and this section, and may, by resolution, fix reasonable fees
to be charged for Municipal activities or services provided pursuant to Section
508 and this section, including, but not limited to, the issuance of
certificates and bills.
(Ord. 4711. Passed 2-8-95.)
244.035 DISPOSITION OF FIRE INSURANCE PROCEEDS; COSTS OF REMOVING, REPAIRING OR
SECURING FIRE-DAMAGED BUILDINGS.
   (a)   The Director of Finance or his or her designee (hereinafter referred
to as the "Municipal Officer") is hereby appointed as the designated officer
who is authorized to carry out all responsibilities and duties of the City, as
provided herein.
   (b)   For purposes of this section, "fire loss" or "claim for fire damage"
means any loss occurring after the effective date of this section and covered
under a policy of fire insurance, including any endorsements or riders to the
policy.
   (c)   No insurance company, association or exchange (hereinafter referred to
as the "insurer") doing business in the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania shall pay
a claim of a named insured for fire damage to a structure located within the
City, where the amount recoverable for the fire loss to the structure under all
policies exceeds seven thousand, five hundred dollars ($7,500), unless the
insurer is furnished by the Municipal Officer with a Municipal certificate
pursuant to Section 508(b) of the Act of May 17, 1921 (P.L. 682, No. 284), and
unless there is compliance with Sections 508(c) and (d) of said Act and the
provisions of this section.
   (d)   After full compliance with the requirements of Section 508(b)(1) (i)
of the Act, the insurer shall pay the claim of the named insured, provided,
however, that if the loss agreed upon by the named insured and the insurer
equals or exceeds sixty percent of the aggregate limits of liability on all
fire policies covering the building structure, the following procedures shall
be followed:
      (1)   The insurer shall transfer from the insurance proceeds to the
Municipal Officer the aggregate of two thousand dollars ($2,000) for each
fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) of a claim and for each fraction of that
amount of a claim, provided that this section is to be applied such that if the
claim is fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) or less, the amount transferred to
the City shall be two thousand dollars ($2,000), and provided, further, that
if, at the time of a loss report, the named insured has submitted a
contractor's signed estimate of the cost of removing, repairing or securing the
building or other structure in an amount less than the amount calculated under
the foregoing transfer formula, the insurer shall transfer to the City from the
insurance proceeds the amount based upon the estimate.
      (2)   The transfer of proceeds shall be on pro rata basis by all
companies, associations or exchanges insuring the building or other structure.
Policy proceeds remaining after the transfer to the City shall be disbursed in
accordance with the policy terms.
   (e)   After the transfer provided in subsection (d) hereof, the named
insured may submit a contractor's signed estimate of the costs of removing,
repairing or securing the building or other structure, and the designated
officer shall return the amount of the funds transferred to the City in excess
of the estimate to the named insured if the City has not commenced to remove,
repair or secure the building or other structure.
   (f)   Upon receipt of proceeds under this section, the City shall do all of
the following:
      (1)   The Municipal Officer shall place the proceeds in a separate fund
to be used solely as security against the total costs of removing, repairing or
securing the building or structure which are incurred by the City. Such costs
shall include, without limitation, any engineering, legal or administrative
costs incurred by the City in connection with such removal, repair or securing
of the building or any proceedings relating thereto.
      (2)   It shall be the obligation of the insurer, when transferring the
proceeds, to provide the City with the name and address of the named insured.
Upon receipt of the transferred funds and the name and address of the named
insured, the Municipal Officer shall contact the named insured, certify that
the proceeds have been received by the City and notify the named insured that
the procedures under this subsection shall be followed.
      (3)   When the repair, removal or securing of the building or other
structure has been completed in accordance with all applicable regulations and
orders of the City and the required proof of such completion received by the
Municipal Officer, and if the City has not incurred any costs for such repair,
removal or securing, the fund shall be returned to the named insured. If the
City has incurred costs for the repair, removal or securing of the building or
other structure, the costs shall be paid from the fund and, if excess funds
remain, the City shall transfer the remaining funds to the named insured.
      (4)   To the extent that interest is earned on proceeds held by the City
pursuant to this section, and retained by it, such interest shall belong to the
City. To the extent that proceeds are returned to the named insured, interest
earned on such proceeds shall be distributed to the named insured at the time
that the proceeds are returned.
   (g)   Nothing in this section shall be construed to limit the ability of the
City to recover any deficiency. Furthermore, nothing in this section shall be
construed to prohibit the City and the named insured from entering into an
agreement that permits the transfer of funds to the named insured if some other
reasonable disposition of the damaged property has been negotiated.
   (h)   The City may, by resolution, adopt procedures and regulations to
implement Section 508 and this section and may, by resolution, fix reasonable
fees to be charged for City activities or services provided pursuant to Section
508 and this section, including, but not limited to, the issuance of
certificates and bills, the performance of inspections and opening of separate
fund accounts.
(Ord. 4710. Passed 2-8-95.)
244.04 COST AND EXPENSE RECOVERY FOR SERVICES PROVIDED.
   (a)   The City wishes to provide for reimbursement for the Fire Department
for any costs and/or expenses incurred by the Department, which may be
attainable, by the Department by submitting claims only to the individual
property owners’ insurance carrier.
   (b)   It is the finding of the City that individual property owners may
maintain insurance coverage within their own casualty insurance policies,
homeowners’ policies and/or other applicable policies that would provide
reimbursement to the Fire Department for fire suppression and other services
rendered to the property owners’ properties in response to emergency service
requests.
   (c)   The City Manager is hereby authorized and directed, by and through the
Office of the Fire Chief, to ascertain what insurance coverages may be
applicable and available under each circumstance, and to take the necessary and
affirmative actions to apply for and receive reimbursement from any insurance
carriers where a property owner is or may be insured to reimburse the
Department for any cost and/or expense incurred for services, supplies and/or
equipment used for or provided to the property owner by their Department. A fee
shall be established by ordinance of City Council and amended from time to time
listing each assessed fee per item of equipment, vehicle, and personnel used by
the Fire Department.
   (d)   Under no circumstances shall the property owner receive a bill from
the City for fire suppression or other services provided by the Department,
with the exception in cases of intentional false alarms and fires intentionally
set by the property owner.
   (e)   This section shall be liberally construed to accomplish its purpose to
compensate and/or reimburse the City from insurance proceeds only the costs
and/or expenses incurred while providing services to their duties for the Fire
Department.
(Ord. 4938. Passed 4-28-04; Ord. 5353. Passed 5-31-23.)
244.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates Section
244.03 or
244.035 shall be subject to a penalty of not more than one thousand dollars
($1,000) per violation.
(Ord. 4710. Passed 2-8-95; Ord. 4711. Passed 2-8-95.)

(Ord. 4389. Passed 9-10-86.)

equipment, supplies, materials and money offered by the Federal Government to
enable the City to carry out any program or activity necessary to the proper
functioning of defense activities in the City. The Director is hereby
authorized to execute such agreements or documents and to agree to such
reasonable terms and conditions as may be required by the Federal Government
for the grant, loan, lease or other use or possession of such equipment,
supplies, materials and money.
(Ord. 4667. Passed 7-13-94.)

Federal and local laws, ordinances and regulations.

procedure for appointment set forth in Section
260.02.
(Ord. 4654. Passed 10-27-93.)
260.04 DETERMINATION OF DUTIES, RESPONSIBILITIES AND MEMBERSHIP OF BOARDS.

and membership of the following boards:

   (c)   The Civil Service Boards;

   (g)   The Waste Water Appeal Board.

Rule Charter shall continue to serve and act subject to all provisions of
applicable State, Federal and local laws, ordinances and regulations. The
existing members of any board shall continue to serve their specific terms
until removal by specific Council action.

in conflict with any provision of the Home Rule Charter shall be amended within
forty-five days of the effective date of the Home Rule Charter.
(Ord. 4654. Passed 10-27-93.)

(Ord. 4654. Passed 10-27-93.)
CHAPTER 262
Authorities
   EDITOR'S NOTE: This chapter has been established to provide a synopsis of
legislation relating to the creation of the following authorities serving the
City:
Johnstown Housing Authority. Pursuant to House Bill No. 753, Act 265, 1937,
Resolution 2727, passed March 5, 1940, declared the need for a housing
authority to function within the territorial limits of the City for the
purposes designated in such Act. An unnumbered resolution of the Board of
County Commissioners, passed November 30, 1949, declared the need for the
Johnstown Housing Authority to function in a portion of the limits of
Stonycreek Township.
Johnstown Parking Authority. Under the provisions of the Act of June 5, 1947
(P.L. 458), as amended, the Johnstown Parking Authority was created by
Ordinance 2923, passed September 19, 1950, as amended by Ordinance 2925, passed
October 10, 1950. Ordinance 4154, passed September 26, 1979, extended the term
of existence of the Authority for fifty years from that date.
Greater Johnstown Water Authority. Under the provisions of the Act of May 2,
1945 (P.L. 382), as amended, the Greater Johnstown Water Authority was created
by Ordinance 3566, passed August 16, 1963. Resolution 7661, passed February 9,
1983, approved amendments to the Articles of Incorporation of the Authority.
Redevelopment Authority. Under the provisions of the Act of May 24, 1945 (P.L.
991), as amended, the Redevelopment Authority of the City was created by
Resolution 3767, passed November 29, 1949.
Johnstown Municipal Authority. Under the provisions of the Act of June 28, 1935
(P.L. 463), as amended, the Johnstown Municipal Authority was created by
Ordinance 2251, passed September 27, 1938, and by Ordinance 2312, passed August
27, 1940. Resolution 5139, passed March 22, 1960, authorized the Authority to
amend its Articles to increase its membership from five to nine. Resolution
5524, passed December 5, 1961, authorized an amendment to decrease the
membership from nine to seven.
Cambria/Somerset Recycling Authority. Under the provisions of the Act of May 2,
1945 (P.L. 382), as amended, the Cambria/Somerset Recycling Authority was
created by Ordinance 4540, passed August 8, 1990.
   Ordinance 4654, passed October 27, 1993, provides that the above-listed
authorities in existence prior to the effective date of the Home Rule Charter
shall continue to serve and act subject to all provisions of applicable State,
Federal and local laws, ordinances and regulations. The existing members of the
boards of such authorities shall continue to serve their specific terms until
removal by specific Council action.
   Any ordinance relating to operations of the above-mentioned authorities
which is in conflict with any provision of the Home Rule Charter shall be
amended within forty-five days of the effective date of the Home Rule Charter.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Municipal Authorities Act - see 53 P.S. Secs. 301 et seq.
   Parking Authorities - see 53 P.S. Sec. 341
   Municipal authorities; cooperation with other political subdivisions - see
3rd Class Sec. 2403(59)

EDITOR'S NOTE: Former

270.02   Purposes, powers and responsibilities.

270.10   Investigations.
270.11   Subpoenas.
270.12   Annual report.
 
270.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Personnel - see H.R. CHTR. Art. IX
   Officers and employees generally - see Opt. 3rd Class §§ 601 et seq., 3rd
Class §§ 901 et seq.; ADM.
Ch. 294
   Appointment and removal of Board of Health employees - see 3rd Class § 2336
   Civil service generally - see 3rd Class §§ 4401 et seq.
   Appointment of department directors - see ADM.
220.03,
223.07
   Department of Fire - see ADM.
Ch. 244
   Boards generally - see ADM.
Ch. 260
270.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established a Civil Service Board for the City to have such
powers and responsibilities as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94.)
270.02 PURPOSES, POWERS AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The purposes, powers and responsibilities of the Civil Service Board are as
follows:
   (a)   To administer, or to designate a recognized examining agency to
administer, entrance and promotion examinations to all applicants for any
police officer or firefighter position, except Chief of Police, Police Captain,
Fire Chief or Deputy Fire Chief.
   (b)   To prepare an eligibility list of those persons who have passed all
examinations for a particular position covered by this chapter and who are
qualified for appointment.
   (c)   To enforce the rules and regulations pertaining to the examination for
appointment to any police officer or firefighter position, except Chief of
Police, Police Captain, Fire Chief or Deputy Fire Chief.
   (d)   To hear appeals pertaining to suspensions, dismissals or reductions in
rank of any police officer or firefighter, except Chief of Police, Police
Captain, Fire Chief or Deputy Fire Chief.
   (e)   To conduct all hearings requested by any police officer or
firefighter, except Chief of Police, Police Captain, Fire Chief or Deputy Fire
Chief, who has been suspended, dismissed or reduced in rank.
   (f)   To issue decisions pertaining to all hearings requested by any police
officer or firefighter, except Chief of Police, Police Captain, Fire Chief or
Deputy Fire Chief, who has been suspended, dismissed or reduced in rank.
   (g)   To establish and amend as necessary the rules and regulations for the
organization and operation of the Board. Such rules and regulations shall be
consistent with the Home Rule Charter, this Administration Code and the
statutes of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania. Such rules and regulations shall
be approved by the City Council.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94; Ord. 4933. Passed 3-10-04.)
270.03 MEMBERSHIP; TERMS; VACANCIES; OATH OF OFFICE.
   The Civil Service Board shall consist of three members who shall be
qualified electors of the City and shall be appointed by the City Council
initially to serve for terms of one, two and three years. As such terms
thereafter expire, members shall be appointed for terms of three years.
   Any vacancy occurring on the Board for any reason whatsoever shall be filled
by the City Council for the unexpired term within thirty days after such
vacancy occurs.
   Each member of the Board, before assuming the duties of his or her office,
shall take an oath or affirmation to support the Constitution of the United
States and of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania and to perform his or her
official duties with fidelity.
   No Board member shall receive compensation, nor shall any Board member, at
the same time, hold any elective or any other appointed office under the
governments of the United States, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania or any
political subdivision of the Commonwealth.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94.)
270.04 ORGANIZATION; QUORUM.
   The Civil Service Board first appointed shall organize within ten days of
its appointment and shall elect one of its members as its Chairperson, one as
Vice-Chairperson and one as Secretary. The Board shall thereafter meet and
organize on the first Monday of June of each even-numbered year. Two members of
the Board shall constitute a quorum, and no action of the Board shall be valid
unless such action has the concurrence of at least two members.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94.)
270.05 DUTIES OF CHAIRPERSON AND SECRETARY.
   (a)   Chairperson. The Chairperson, or, in his or her absence, the Vice-
Chairperson, shall preside at all meetings and hearings of the Civil Service
Board, decide all points of order or procedure and perform any duties required
by law or the rules and regulations of the Board.
   (b)   Secretary. The Secretary shall carry on, at the direction of the
Board, all official correspondence of the Board, send out all notices required
by law and the rules and regulations of the Board, keep a record of each
examination or other official action of the Board, and perform all other duties
required by law or the rules and regulations of the Board.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94.)
270.06 MEETINGS.
   Except for the biennial organization meeting, all meetings of the Civil
Service Board shall be held either at the call of the Chairperson or at the
call of two members of the Board. The Board shall have the discretion to
determine whether meetings shall be open to the public when not specifically
regulated by law or Board rules and regulations.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94.)
270.07 STAFF SUPPORT.
   The Civil Service Board shall have no permanently assigned staff. Staff
support and necessary supplies shall be provided by the City Manager or his or
her designee. In addition, the Board may retain counsel and any other
consultants or experts, including testing agencies, physicians and
psychiatrists, as necessary and approved by the City Council.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94.)
270.08 RULES AND REGULATIONS; AMENDMENTS.
   The Civil Service Board shall adopt, subject to the approval of the City
Council, rules and regulations to govern its operations.
   The Board may amend, revise, void or replace its rules and regulations for
any reason by action of a majority of the Board at any properly convened
meeting, subject to approval of the City Council.
   Board rules and regulations, and any amendments thereto, shall be made
available to the public at the office of the City Clerk for distribution or
inspection.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94.)
270.09 MINUTES AND RECORDS.
   The Civil Service Board shall keep minutes of its proceedings and records of
examinations and other official action. All records of the Board shall be
preserved and disposed of according to the Retention and Disposition Schedule
for Records of Pennsylvania Municipalities issued by the Local Government
Records Committee under the authority of the Municipal Records Act. A certified
copy of all meetings and action taken shall be filed in the City Clerk's office
within fifteen days of said meeting.
   Any and all records related to any disciplinary action filed with the Board
shall be open to public inspection, subject to reasonable regulation. The Board
Secretary shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member
upon each question. If a member is absent or fails to vote, the Secretary shall
indicate that fact in the minutes.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94.)
270.10 INVESTIGATIONS.
   The Civil Service Board shall have the power to make investigations
concerning all matters relating to the administration and enforcement of its
rules and regulations. The Chairperson of the Board is authorized to administer
oaths and affirmations in connection with such investigations.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94.)
270.11 SUBPOENAS.
   The Civil Service Board shall have the power to issue subpoenas over the
signature of the Chairperson, or his or her designee, to acquire the attendance
of witnesses and the production of records and papers pertaining to any
investigation, hearing or inquiry authorized by its rules and regulations.
   All officers in public service and employees of the City shall attend and
testify when required to do so by the Board.
   No person shall refuse or neglect to obey any subpoena issued by the Board.
   If any person refuses or neglects to obey any subpoena, the Board may apply
by petition to the Court of Common Pleas of Cambria County for its subpoena,
requiring the attendance of such person before the Board or the Court to
testify and to produce any records and papers necessary, and, in default
thereof, such person shall be held in contempt of court.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94.)
270.12 ANNUAL REPORT.
   The Civil Service Board shall make an annual report to the City Council
containing a brief summary of its work during the year. The annual report shall
be available for public inspection.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94.)
270.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00) and, in
default of the payment of such fine, shall be imprisoned not more than thirty
days.
(Ord. 4665. Passed 5-11-94.)
CHAPTER 272
Advisory Recreation Commission
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Former
Chapter 272, titled Municipal Recreation Commission, and being a codification
of Ordinance 3499, passed December 5, 1961, and Ordinance 4389, passed
September 10, 1986, was repealed in its entirety and re-enacted by Ordinance
4663, passed May 11, 1994.
272.01   Establishment.
272.02   Purposes, powers and responsibilities.
272.03   Membership; appointments; terms; vacancies; quorum.
272.04   Attendance.
272.05   Compensation.
272.06   Organization; election of officers.
272.07   Meetings.
272.08   Rules and regulations.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Appointment of commissions - see Opt. 3rd Class § 410
   Condemnation of property for recreation places - see 3rd Class § 2801
   Parks generally - see 3rd Class §§ 3701 et seq.; S.U. & P.S.
Ch. 1062
   Creation, composition and organization - see 3rd Class §§ 3704 et seq.
   Department of Recreation - see ADM.
Ch. 245
   Commissions generally - see ADM.
Ch. 260
272.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established an Advisory Recreation Commission for the City,
to have such powers and responsibilities as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 4663. Passed 5-11-94.)
272.02 PURPOSES, POWERS AND RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The purposes, powers and responsibilities of the Advisory Recreation
Commission are as follows:
   (a)   To provide advice, guidance and recommendations to the City Council on
all matters pertaining to recreation facilities, programs and needs;
   (b)   To promote City recreation programs and recreation volunteerism; and
   (c)   To prepare, for City Council consideration, a City recreation vision
or master plan of year-round passive and active recreation programs for
residents and visitors of all ages and social groups.
   The Commission shall have no administrative duties or authority; no
authority to spend or commit funds unless specifically authorized by the City
Council; and no authority to enter into contracts of any nature.
(Ord. 4663. Passed 5-11-94.)
272.03 MEMBERSHIP; APPOINTMENTS; TERMS; VACANCIES; QUORUM.
   (a)   The Advisory Recreation Commission shall be comprised of seven members
who shall be appointed as follows: three members of City Council appointed by a
majority vote of Council; four at-large members appointed by a majority of
Council, and who shall be City residents.
   Four members of the Commission shall constitute a quorum for the transaction
of business. All actions of the Commission shall be by recorded vote and the
affirmative vote of at least four members shall be necessary for the adoption
of any motion.
   (b)   Three of the original appointments to the Commission shall be for a
term of three years; two of the original appointments shall be for a term of
two years; and two of the original appointments shall be for a term of one
year.
   (c)   The expiration date for all terms of office shall be January 1 of the
appropriate year.
   (d)   Vacancies caused by death, resignation or otherwise on the Commission
shall be promptly filled by the City Council for the unexpired term of office.
(Ord. 4663. Passed 5-11-94; Ord. 4678. Passed 9-28-94.)
272.04 ATTENDANCE.
   (a)   Members of the Advisory Recreation Commission shall attend at least
two-thirds of all regularly scheduled and held meetings within any twelve-month
period. If any member does not attend such prescribed number of meetings, it
shall be grounds for the Commission to recommend to the City Council that the
position be declared vacant and a replacement appointed.
   (b)   The attendance of all Commission members shall be entered upon the
minutes of all meetings by the Secretary.
(Ord. 4663. Passed 5-11-94.)
272.05 COMPENSATION.
   All members of the Advisory Recreation Commission shall serve without
compensation except for reimbursement of necessary expenses when provided for
in the budget.
(Ord. 4663. Passed 5-11-94.)
272.06 ORGANIZATION; ELECTION OF OFFICERS.
   (a)   The officers of the Advisory Recreation Commission shall be a
Chairperson, a Vice-Chairperson and a Secretary. All officers shall be members
of the Commission.
   (b)   At the initial meeting of the Commission and at the first meeting in
January of each year, the Commission shall elect the above identified officers
to serve one-year terms of office. All officers shall be eligible to serve
successive terms of office.
(Ord. 4663. Passed 5-11-94.)
272.07 MEETINGS.
   (a)   The Advisory Recreation Commission shall hold an organizational
meeting as soon as possible after the Commission is established and the initial
appointments made.
   (b)   The Commission shall meet not less than bi-monthly.
   (c)   Special meetings may be called by the Chairperson or at the written
request of three members.
   (d)   All meetings shall be called and held in conformance with the
Pennsylvania Sunshine Law.
   (e)   A copy of the minutes of all regular and special meetings of the
Commission shall be filed with the City Council within fifteen working days
after each meeting.
(Ord. 4663. Passed 5-11-94.)
272.08 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Advisory Recreation Commission may adopt such rules and regulations to
govern its internal organization and procedure as it may deem necessary and
which are not in conflict with this chapter, this Administration Code or other
resolutions and decisions of the City Council. Such rules and regulations, upon
their adoption, shall immediately be provided to the City Council and to the
City Manager.
(Ord. 4663. Passed 5-11-94.)

CHAPTER 277
Redevelopment Authority Designated as Land Bank
277.01     Purpose and authority.
277.02   Definitions.
277.03   Designation.
277.04   Powers of Authority as a land bank.
277.05   Community representation on Board of the Authority.
277.06   Action taken by Board of the Authority.
277.07   Acquisition of real property.
277.08   Policies.
277.09   Financial provisions.
277.10   Revocation of the designation.
277.01 PURPOSE AND AUTHORITY.
   (a)   It is the purpose of this chapter to designate the Johnstown
Redevelopment Authority to act as a land bank for the City of Johnstown
pursuant to the authority granted under Act 33 of 2018, P.L. 221 (June 19,
2018) which amended the Pennsylvania Land Bank Law, 68 Pa. C.S. §§ 2101-2120.
   (b)   The City of Johnstown is designating the Johnstown Redevelopment
Authority to act as a land bank in order to mitigate blight, encourage the
redevelopment of vacant, abandoned, and tax-delinquent properties, foster
economic development of these properties, and improve the quality of life of
neighborhoods affected by these properties.
(Ord. 5326. Passed 1-12-22.)
277.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the following
meanings:
   (a)   "Act 33 of 2018." The act of June 19, 2018, P.L. 221, No. 33, codified
at 68 Pa. C.S. § 2104(h).
   (b)   "Authority." Johnstown Redevelopment Authority, a redevelopment
authority created for the City of Johnstown and operating under the act of May
24, 1945 (P.L. 991, No. 385), known as the Urban Redevelopment Law.
   (c)   "Authority as land bank." The Authority when acting as a land bank
pursuant to the Land Bank Law and this chapter.
   (d)   "Land bank activities." Any and all activities, operations, actions
and functions undertaken by the Authority pursuant to the Land Bank Law and
this chapter.
   (e)   "Land Bank Law." The act of October 24, 2012, P.L. 1239, No. 153,
codified at 68 Pa. C.S. §§ 2102-2120 and any amendments thereto.
   (f)   "Owner-Occupant." A natural person with a legal or equitable ownership
in the property which was the primary residence of the person for at least
three consecutive months at any point in the year preceding the date of the
initial delinquency.
   (g)   "Person." A corporation, partnership, limited liability company,
business trust, other association, government entity (other than the
Commonwealth of Pennsylvania), estate, trust or natural person.
   (h)   "Policies." The rules, policies and procedures adopted by the
Authority pursuant to this chapter and the Land Bank Law.
   (i)   "Real property." Land and all structures and fixtures thereon and all
estates and interests in land, including easements, covenants and leaseholder.
(Ord. 5326. Passed 1-12-22.)
277.03 DESIGNATION.
   The Authority is hereby designated as the land bank for the City of
Johnstown pursuant to Act 33 of 2018 and § 2104(h)(1) of the Land Bank Law, 68
Pa. C.S. § 2104(h).
(Ord. 5326. Passed 1-12-22.)
277.04 POWERS OF AUTHORITY AS A LAND BANK.
   The Authority shall have all the powers conferred upon a land bank under the
Land Bank Law, including but not limited to § 2107.
(Ord. 5326. Passed 1-12-22.)
277.05 COMMUNITY REPRESENTATION ON BOARD OF THE AUTHORITY.
   (a)   A Board shall be created for the executive action of Johnstown
Redevelopment Authority (JRA) as a land bank. Board members of JRA as a land
bank will consist of all current JRA Board members with terms concurrent to
their terms as Authority board members.
   (b)   Upon a vacancy or expiration of the term of an Authority's board
member occurring after designation of the Authority pursuant to this chapter,
the City of Johnstown shall appoint replacements to the Authority's board and
ensure that at least one voting board member (i) is a resident of for City of
Johnstown; (ii) is not a public official or municipal employee, and (iii)
maintains membership with a recognized civic organization within the
jurisdiction of City of Johnstown.
   (c)   Any person may submit recommendations to City of Johnstown concerning
membership of the Authority's Board and appointments thereto by City of
Johnstown.
(Ord. 5326. Passed 1-12-22.)
277.06 ACTION TAKEN BY BOARD OF THE AUTHORITY.
   All action taken by the Board of the Authority must be done in compliance
with § 2105(h) of the Land Bank Law.
(Ord. 5326. Passed 1-12-22.)
277.07 ACQUISITION OF REAL PROPERTY.
   (a)   The Authority as land bank shall hold title in its own name to all
real property it acquires.
   (b)   The Authority as land bank may acquire real property by any legal
means, on terms and conditions and in a manner the Authority considers proper.
   (c)   If the Authority as land bank acquires a residential property occupied
by owner- occupants, it shall be the Authority's policy to show a preference
for keeping the owner- occupants within their homes.
   (d)   The Authority as land bank shall acquire, hold and dispose of real
property in accordance with the Land Bank Law.
   (e)   Any person may submit recommendations to the Authority concerning real
property that could be acquired and the proposed uses for which such property
could be redeveloped.
(Ord. 5326. Passed 1-12-22.)
277.08 POLICIES.
   (a)   The Authority shall develop policies which are consistent with the
Land Bank Law and with this chapter.
   (b)   After the adoption of the policies by the Authority, the policies
shall be reviewed at least annually by the Authority with the opportunity for
public input and comment. The policies shall be published on the Authority's
website.
   (c)   The policies adopted by the Authority shall include ethical standards,
financial disclosure standards and conflict of interest guidelines consistent
with § 2115 of the Land Bank Law and all other applicable state and local laws.
(Ord. 5326. Passed 1-12-22.)
277.09 FINANCIAL PROVISIONS.
   (a)   The Authority shall finance land bank activities through any means
authorized under the Land Bank Law or any other applicable law.
   (b)   Finances of the Authority as land bank shall be retained and accounted
for separately from finances held for other Authority purposes and shall be
subject to the annual auditing and reporting requirements of § 2119 of the Land
Bank Law.
(Ord. 5326. Passed 1-12-22.)
277.10 REVOCATION OF THE DESIGNATION.
   The designation of the Authority as land bank may be revoked in the same
manner as the dissolution of a land bank under § 2114 of the Land Bank Law.
(Ord. 5326. Passed 1-12-22.)
CHAPTER 278
Vacant Property Review Committee
278.01   Short title.
278.02   Purpose and intent.
278.03   Composition; terms of office; officers.
278.04   Duties of Secretary.
278.05   Blighted property defined.
278.06   Residential and related uses defined.
278.07   Certification of blighted property to Redevelopment Authority.
278.08   Powers of Redevelopment Authority.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Authority to establish - see Opt. 3rd Class § 410
   Temporary tax exemption for residential construction - see 3rd Class §
2504.1
   Sale of property for delinquent taxes - see 3rd Class §§ 2541 et seq.
   Sale of property purchased from Tax Claim Bureau - see 3rd Class §§ 2560 et
seq.
   Acquisition of lands and buildings - see 3rd Class § 3703
   Sale of unused and unnecessary land and buildings - see 3rd Class § 3721
   Tax exemptions for improvement of property - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 876,
Ch. 878
   Vacant structures - see B. & H.
Ch. 1480
278.01 SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Act 94 Vacant Property
Review Committee of the City of Johnstown."
(Ord. 4127. Passed 12-27-78.)
278.02 PURPOSE AND INTENT.
   The purpose and intent of this chapter are to establish a Vacant Property
Review Committee of the City to implement the provisions of the Urban
Redevelopment Law of 1945, as amended by Act 94 of 1978, as amended.
(Ord. 4127. Passed 12-27-78.)
278.03 COMPOSITION; TERMS OF OFFICE; OFFICERS.
   The Vacant Property Review Committee shall be made up of:
   (a)   That member of Council who is then serving as Chairperson of Council's
Committee on Community Development and Planning, who shall act as Chairperson
of the Vacant Property Review Committee and who shall serve upon the Vacant
Property Review Committee and as Chairperson thereof only so long as he or she
continues as Chairperson of the Committee on Community Development and
Planning;
   (b)   That member of the Board of Directors of the Redevelopment Authority
of the City who shall be appointed by the majority vote of the Council, which
appointment shall be made within thirty days of the enactment of this chapter
(Ordinance 4127, passed December 27, 1978), and appointed by a majority of
Council within thirty days of any vacancy in this position on the Vacant
Property Review Committee that occurs hereafter. Such member shall serve for a
term of three years, but with the first term hereunder ending on December 31,
1979. However, if a vacancy occurs for any reason other than the completion of
the term of the former member of the Committee, the new member of the Committee
who is appointed to replace the former member of the Committee shall serve only
to the end of the term of the former member of the Committee who he or she is
replacing and shall serve upon the Committee only so long as he or she
continues as a member of the Board of Directors of the Redevelopment Authority.
Further, such member shall act as Vice-Chairperson of the Committee while a
member of the Committee.
   (c)   That member of the Board of Directors of the Housing Authority of the
City who shall be appointed by the majority vote of the Council, which
appointment shall be made within thirty days of the enactment of this chapter
(Ordinance 4127, passed December 27, 1978), and appointed by a majority of
Council within thirty days of any vacancy in this position on the Committee
that occurs hereafter. Such member shall serve for a term of three years, but
with the first term hereunder ending on December 31, 1980. However, if a
vacancy occurs for any reason other than the completion of the term of the
former member of the Committee, the new member of the Committee who is
appointed to replace the former member of the Committee shall serve only to the
end of the term of the former member of the Committee who he or she is
replacing and shall serve upon the Committee only so long as he or she
continues as a member of the Board of Directors of the Housing Authority.
   (d)   That member of the Planning Commission of the City who shall be
appointed by the majority vote fo the Council, which appointment shall be made
within thirty days of the enactment of this chapter (Ordinance 4127, passed
December 27, 1978), and appointed by a majority of Council within thirty days
of any vacancy in this position on the Committee that occurs hereafter. Such
member shall serve for a term of three years, but with the first term hereunder
ending on December 31, 1980. However, if a vacancy occurs for any reason other
than the completion of the term of the former member of the Committee, the new
member of the Committee who is appointed to replace the former member of the
Committee shall serve only to the end of the term of the former member of the
Committee who he or she is replacing and shall serve upon the Committee only so
long as he or she continues as a member of the Planning Commission. Further,
such member shall act as Assistant Secretary of the Committee while a member of
the Committee.
   (e)   That member of the executive branch of the City who shall be appointed
by the majority vote of the Council, which appointment shall be made within
thirty days of the enactment of this chapter (Ordinance 4127, passed December
27, 1978), and appointed by a majority of Council within thirty days of any
vacancy in this position on the Committee that occurs hereafter. Such member
shall serve for a term of three years, but with the first term hereunder ending
on December 31, 1981. However, if a vacancy occurs for any reason other than
the completion of the term of the former member of the Committee, the new
member of the Committee who is appointed to replace the former member of the
Committee shall serve only to the end of the term of the former member of the
Committee who he or she is replacing and shall serve upon the Committee only so
long as he or she continues as a member of the executive branch of the City.
Further, such member shall act as Secretary of the Committee while a member of
the Committee.
(Ord. 4667. Passed 7-13-94; Ord. 4910. Passed 4-9-03.)
278.04 DUTIES OF SECRETARY.
   The Secretary, or the Assistant Secretary in his or her place, of the Vacant
Property Review Committee shall:
   (a)   Act as Secretary of the Committee;
   (b)   Notify, in writing, the City Manager and Council of any vacancies on
the Committee; and
   (c)   Certify blighted properties to the Redevelopment Authority of the City
in accordance with Section
278.07.
(Ord. 4667. Passed 7-13-94.)
278.05 BLIGHTED PROPERTY DEFINED.
   As used in this chapter, "blighted properties" means:
   (a)   Any premises which, because of its physical condition or use, is
regarded as a public nuisance at common law or has been declared a public
nuisance in accordance with the local housing, building, plumbing, fire and
related codes;
   (b)   Any premises which, because of its physical condition, use or
occupancy, is considered an attractive nuisance to children, including, but not
limited to, abandoned wells, shafts, basements and excavations and unsafe
fences or structures;
   (c)   Any dwelling which, because it is dilapidated, unsanitary, unsafe,
vermin-infested or lacking in the facilities and equipment required by the BOCA
National Property Maintenance Code, as adopted in
Chapter 1428  of Part Fourteen - the Building and Housing Code, has been
designated by the Code Enforcement Division of the Department of Community and
Economic Development as unfit for human habitation;
   (d)   Any structure which is a fire hazard or is otherwise dangerous to the
safety of persons or property;
   (e)   Any structure from which the utilities, plumbing, heating, sewerage or
other facilities have been disconnected, destroyed, removed or rendered
ineffective so that the property is unfit for its intended use;
   (f)   Any vacant or unimproved lot or parcel of ground in a predominantly
built-up neighborhood, which lot or parcel, by reason of neglect or lack of
maintenance, has become a place for the accumulation of trash and debris or a
haven for rodents or other vermin;
   (g)   Any unoccupied property which has been tax delinquent for a period of
two years prior to the effective date of this chapter (Ordinance 4127, passed
December 27, 1978) and any unoccupied property in the future that has a two-
year tax delinquency; and
   (h)   Any property which is vacant, but not tax delinquent, and which has
not been rehabilitated within one year of the receipt of notice to rehabilitate
from the Code Enforcement Division of the Department of Community and Economic
Development.
(Ord. 4667. Passed 7-13-94.)
278.06 RESIDENTIAL AND RELATED USES DEFINED.
   (a)   As used in this chapter, "residential and related uses" include
residential property for sale or rental and related uses, including, but not
limited to, park and recreation areas, neighborhood community services and
neighborhood parking lots.
   (b)   The land may also be used for commercial or industrial reuse.
(Ord. 4127. Passed 12-27-78; Ord. 4951. Passed 11-17-04.)
278.07 CERTIFICATION OF BLIGHTED PROPERTY TO REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY.
   The Vacant Property Review Committee and the Planning Commission of the
City, upon making a determination that any property is blighted, as set forth
in Section
278.05, shall certify such blighted property to the Redevelopment Authority of
the City, except that:
   (a)   No property shall be certified to the Redevelopment Authority unless
it is vacant.
   (b)   No property shall be certified to the Redevelopment Authority unless
the owner of the property or an agent designated by him or her for receipt of
service of notices within the Municipality has been served with notice of the
determination that the property is blighted, together with an appropriate order
to eliminate the conditions causing the blight, and notice that failure to do
so may render the property subject to condemnation under this chapter. The
notice shall be served upon the owner or his or her agent in accordance with
local ordinances pertaining to service of notice of determination of a public
nuisance. The owner or his or her agent shall have the right of appeal from the
determination in the same manner as an appeal from the determination of a
public nuisance.
   (c)   No blighted property shall be certified to the Redevelopment Authority
until the time period for appeal has expired and no appeal has been taken, or,
if taken, until the appeal has been disposed of and the owner or his or her
agent has failed to comply with the order of the responsible department or
other officer or agency.
   (d)   No single vacant lot or parcel of ground on which more than ten
dwelling units can be constructed under existing zoning regulations shall be
certified to the Redevelopment Authority under this section.
(Ord. 4127. Passed 12-27-78.)
278.08 POWERS OF REDEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY.
   The Redevelopment Authority of the City is hereby granted all of the powers
of redevelopment authorities which are set forth in Act 94 of 1978, amending
the Urban Redevelopment Law, being the Act of May 24, 1974 (P.L. 991, No. 385).
(Ord. 4127. Passed 12-27-78.)

CHAPTER 282
Board of Trustees of the Comprehensive Municipal Pension Trust Fund
282.01   Establishment.
282.02   Membership.
282.03   Terms; vacancies.
282.04   Compensation.
282.05   Quorum.
282.06   Powers and duties.
282.07   Interpretation of chapter.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Restrictions on municipal powers as to retirement - see Opt. 3rd Class § 305
   Pensions generally - see 3rd Class §§ 4301 et seq.
   Comprehensive Municipal Pension Trust Fund - see ADM.
Ch. 285
282.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established, pursuant to the requirements of the Municipal
Pension Plan Funding Standard and Recovery Act (Act 205 of 1984 (P.L. 1005), 53
P.S. 895.101 et seq.), hereinafter referred to as "the Act," a board of
trustees to be known as the Board of Trustees of the Comprehensive Municipal
Pension Trust Fund. Such Board shall establish a trust fund to be known as the
Comprehensive Municipal Pension Trust Fund and shall invest and otherwise
manage the assets of such Fund in accordance with the requirements of the Act.
(Ord. 4418. Passed 12-31-86.)
282.02 MEMBERSHIP.
   The Board of Trustees of the Comprehensive Municipal Pension Trust Fund
shall consist of eleven members to be determined according to the requirements
of Act 205 of 1984 (P.L. 1005). The City Manager, the Director of Finance and
the Finance Accounting Assistant shall be members of the Board. Four members of
the Board shall be appointed by the Council, by majority vote, from the
managing boards of the City’s various pension plans. The remaining four members
of the Board of Trustees shall consist of one representative of the active
membership of each pension plan included in the Comprehensive Municipal Pension
Trust Fund, which representative shall be elected by the active membership of
each respective pension plan.
(Ord. 4667. Passed 7-13-94; Ord. 4930. Passed 2-11-04; Ord. 5136. Passed 10-23-
13.)
282.03 TERMS; VACANCIES.
   Each appointed member of the Board of Trustees of the Comprehensive
Municipal Pension Trust Fund shall serve for a term of four years, provided
that the member continues to hold a position on the managing board of one of
the City's pension plans. Any vacancies created by the resignation, death or
removal of an appointed member shall be filled by appointment of the Council,
by a majority vote, for the unexpired portion of the appointed member's term.
Each elected member of the Board shall serve for a term of four years. Any
vacancies created by the resignation, death or removal of an elected member
shall be filled by a special election of the active membership of the
applicable pension plan for the unexpired portion of the elected member's term.
(Ord. 4667. Passed 7-13-94.)
282.04 COMPENSATION.
   Members of the Board of Trustees of the Comprehensive Municipal Pension
Trust Fund shall serve without compensation. This provision, however, shall not
be deemed to prevent reimbursement for proper expenses incurred in the
performance of a trustee's duties and approved by the Board.
(Ord. 4418. Passed 12-31-86.)
282.05 QUORUM.
   A majority of the eleven members of the Board of Trustees of the
Comprehensive Municipal Pension Trust Fund shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of any business or for a decision on any matter within its
jurisdiction, and a majority of such quorum shall be sufficient to decide such
matters.
(Ord. 4418. Passed 12-31-86.)
282.06 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Board of Trustees of the Comprehensive Municipal Pension Trust Fund,
acting by a quorum of its members, shall have the following powers and duties:
   (a)   To establish a trust fund to be known as the Comprehensive Municipal
Pension Trust Fund, which Trust Fund shall receive, and shall act as a
repository for, assets amassed by the City's various pension plans, and from
which Trust Fund the payment of pension benefits and pension administrative
costs shall henceforth be made in accordance with the procedures provided for
in subsection (c) hereof;
   (b)   To invest and manage the assets of the Comprehensive Municipal Pension
Trust Fund and to account for the individual interests of the various pension
plans in such Trust Fund;
   (c)   To establish procedures, in accordance with applicable law, to provide
access by the various pension plans to their respective interests in the Trust
Fund for the payment of benefits and administrative expenses associated with
each plan and to facilitate the payment and/or deposit of contributions to the
Trust Fund;
   Board of Trustees of the Comprehensive
   (d)   To contract for investment and consulting services;
   (e)   To assess reasonable administrative expenses of the Board against the
assets of the Trust Fund; and
   (f)   To exercise and perform any and all other powers granted and duties
prescribed under Act 205 of 1984 (P.L. 1005), as amended.
(Ord. 4418. Passed 12-31-86.)
282.07 INTERPRETATION OF CHAPTER.
   This chapter shall be construed in accordance with the Municipal Pension
Plan Funding Standard and Recovery Act, Act 205 of 1984 (P.L. 1005), as
amended.
(Ord. 4418. Passed 12-31-86.)
CHAPTER 283
Loan Review Committee
283.01   Establishment.
283.02   Eligibility; membership.
283.03   Terms.
283.04   Meetings; quorum; voting.
283.05   Records.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   General Code penalty - see ADM. 202.99
283.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   A Loan Review Committee is hereby created and established consisting of
seven persons who shall be selected by the City Manager, and confirmed by a
resolution of City Council. The Council shall vote in support of the
confirmation or rejection of the City Manager's selection of persons, but shall
not confirm persons not submitted by the City Manager.
(Ord. 5230. Passed 5-16-17.)
283.02 ELIGIBILITY; MEMBERSHIP.
   (a)   No City employee, department head or member of any other board,
authority or commission shall be eligible to serve on the Loan Review
Committee, as a voting member.
   (b)   The Loan Review Committee membership shall be comprised of no fewer
than two members who shall be City of Johnstown residents and registered voters
in the City of Johnstown, and five members from the business community, banking
institutions at the discretion of the City Manager.
(Ord. 5230. Passed 5-16-17.)
283.03 TERMS.
   Initial appointments shall be for staggered terms with two appointments
being for a one-year term; two appointments being for a two-year term; and
three appointments being for a three-year term.
(Ord. 5230. Passed 5-16-17.)
283.04 MEETINGS; QUORUM; VOTING.
   (a)   All meetings held by the Loan Review Committee shall be subject to all
provisions of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Sunshine Act, 65 Pa. C.S. §§ 701
et seq., as amended by Act of June 30, 2011, No. 56, and require a quorum, four
of the seven members of the Loan Review Committee in attendance to take any
official actions.
   (b)   No votes by any member of the Loan Review Committee shall be permitted
to be cast by telephone (land or cell), nor by text messaging, nor by e-mail
transmissions.
(Ord. 5230. Passed 5-16-17.)
283.05 RECORDS.
   (a)   Official minutes of all Loan Review Committee meetings and/or workshop
sessions shall be kept and maintained in the offices of the City Manager under
provisions of the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania Record Retention Act.
   (b)   Secretarial and/or stenographer service shall be provided for all Loan
Review Committee.
(Ord. 5230. Passed 5-16-17.)

   The Council shall establish, provide and maintain, by ordinance, pension
and/or retirement board(s) and fund(s) for eligible employees and officials.
(Ord. 4654. Passed 10-27-93.)
284.5.02 AMENDMENTS TO PENSION ORDINANCES.
   Any pension ordinance in effect prior to the effective date of the Home Rule
Charter shall be amended to provide that:
   (a)   The City Manager, the Director of Finance and the City Clerk shall
serve on respective boards and funds, previously being held by the Mayor, the
City Controller and the Director of Finance.
   (b)   Appointments to any board required by existing local ordinance or
State statue shall be made by a vote of the majority of Council.
   (c)   All ordinances shall be adopted or amended so as to be in compliance
with all requirements of the Municipal Pension Plan Funding Standard Recovery
Act, Act 205 of 1984, or any mandated pension requirements.
   (d)   Certified copies of all official proceedings of pension funds and
retirement boards shall be filed with the office of the City Clerk within
fifteen days of such action.
(Ord. 4654. Passed 10-27-93.)
CHAPTER 285
Comprehensive Municipal Pension Trust Fund
EDITOR'S NOTE: The City has elected, by Resolutions 7769, passed December 31,
1985, and 7814, passed December 10, 1986, to establish a Comprehensive
Municipal Pension Trust Fund, as authorized by Act 205 of 1984 (P.L. 1005), as
amended. This Trust Fund shall act as a repository for the assets amassed by
the City's various pension plans, and the payment of pension benefits and
pension administrative costs shall be made from such Trust Fund.
   A Board of Trustees of the Comprehensive Municipal Pension Trust Fund has
been established to administer such Fund. See
Chapter 282.
   There are no sections in
Chapter 285. This chapter has been established to provide a place for cross
