440.01 HUMAN-POWERED VEHICLES.
   (a)   Definitions. Unless the context otherwise requires, the following
words or phrases shall be construed according to the definitions set forth
below:
      (1)   "Pedal cycle" means a vehicle propelled solely by human-powered
pedals.
      (2)   "Traffic way" means the entire width between property lines, or
other boundary lines, of every way or place, any part of which are open to the
public for purposes of vehicular travel as a matter of right or custom.
   (b)   Violations.
      (1)   No person shall ride upon or utilize in any manner upon the streets
or sidewalks in the City any skateboard, roller skates, scooter or any other
human-powered device, other than a pedal cycle.
      (2)   Any person riding upon or utilizing any skateboard, roller skates,
scooter or any other human-powered device, other than a pedal cycle, in an
alley, playground or any other place open to pedestrian traffic not prohibited
by this section, shall yield right of way to any pedestrian and shall utilize
such device with all due regard to the safety of pedestrians and property.
   (3)   No person shall erect or place any type of ramp, designed for use with
skateboards, roller skates, scooters, pedal cycles or any other human-powered
vehicles, onto the streets, alleys, sidewalks and traffic ways in the City.
      (4)   Repeated violations of this section, or refusal to comply, shall be
cause for seizure of the device or devices being used in violation of this
section.
      (5)   No person shall ride upon or utilize in any manner upon playgrounds
in the City any skateboard, roller skates, roller blades, scooter, pedal cycle
or any other human powered device unless so designated.
   (c)   Enforcement. It shall be the duty of the Johnstown Police Department
to enforce the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 4541. Passed 9-12-90; Ord. 4868. Passed 1-24-01.)
440.02 PARADES AND ASSEMBLAGES.
   Parades, processions, assemblages or meetings occupying, marching or
assembling upon any street, lane, alley or public square of the City are hereby
prohibited, unless written notice of the character, time, place and route of
such parade or procession, and the names of the officers of the same, are given
by the chief officer thereof to the City Manager, or, in the case of
assemblages or meetings, unless twenty-four hours notice of the object, time
and place of such assemblage or meeting is given to the City Manager by the
persons making application for the permit as hereinafter provided.
   In pursuance of the aforesaid requirements and for the purpose of preventing
interference with and obstruction of the lawful use of streets, lanes, alleys
or public squares of the City, and for the preservation of peace and good
order, the City Manager may designate, by permit, the time and place of an
assemblage or meeting, and in the case of a parade or procession, how much of
the streets, lanes, alleys or public squares it will occupy and the time of
starting. The length of time of such parade or procession shall be determined
by the City Manager, and, when so designated and approved, the proper officers
of such parade or procession shall be held responsible for the violation of any
designation or limitation mentioned in such permit.
(Ord. 4668. Passed 7-13-94.)
440.03 USE OF AREAS BY UTILITY COMPANIES; PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE.
   No utility company in the City shall use any street in the City, by its
servants, agents, workers and employees or independent contractors, in a
metered or unmetered area, for the purpose of making repairs, excavations or
construction or reconstruction of facilities, which activities would impede and
interfere with the usual and customary flow of traffic, without first obtaining
a permit therefor. The fee for such permit shall be established by ordinance of
City Council and amended from time to time. The fee shall be for the use of all
City-owned streets.
(Ord. 4528. Passed 2-28-90; Ord. 5353. Passed 5-31-23.)
440.04 OBSTRUCTION OF ROADWAYS BY IMMOBILE VEHICLES.
   No person, whose vehicle has had a mechanical failure so that it can no
longer proceed under its own motive power, in the line of any public street,
alley or other public way in the City, shall fail to have the same removed
within not more than three hours from the time of such break-down, unless the
same occurs at night, in which case he or she shall cause red or amber warning
lights to be placed on or around the vehicle so as to prevent accidents by
persons driving or otherwise passing along the street, alley or other public
way and, further, shall cause the removal of the vehicle before 9:00 a.m. of
the following day.
(Ord. 4528. Passed 2-28-90.)
440.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
422.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of Section
440.01 shall be fined twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the first offense, fifty
dollars ($50.00) for the second offense, seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for the
third offense, and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for each subsequent offense.
(Ord. 4868. Passed 1-24-01.)
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of Section
440.11 shall be fined twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for the first and second
offense and one hundred dollars ($100.00) for a third and subsequent offense.
(Ord. 4541. Passed 9-12-90.)
CHAPTER 442
Pedestrians
442.01   Blind persons.
442.02   Application of traffic control signals.
442.03   Use of right half of crosswalks.

   CROSS REFERENCES

seq.
   Pedestrian control signals - see Vehicle Code § 3113
   Pedestrians generally - see Vehicle Code §§ 3541 et seq.
442.01 BLIND PERSONS.
   No person, except a person wholly or partially blind, shall carry or use in
the City, on any street or alley in the City, any cane or walking stick that is
white or white with a red tip.
(Ord. 2292. Passed 12-12-39.)
442.02 APPLICATION OF TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNALS.
   Pedestrians shall be subject to traffic control signals. Pedestrians shall
be granted all rights and shall be subject to all restrictions provided for in
this Traffic Code.
(Ord. 3639. Passed 3-19-65.)
442.03 USE OF RIGHT HALF OF CROSSWALKS.
   Pedestrians shall move, whenever practical, upon the right half of
crosswalks.
(Ord. 3639. Passed 3-19-65.)
442.04 CROSSING IN CENTRAL TRAFFIC DISTRICT AND BUSINESS DISTRICTS.
   No pedestrian shall cross a roadway other than in a crosswalk in the central
traffic district or in any business district.
(Ord. 3639. Passed 3-19-65.)
442.05 RESPONSIBILITY OF DRIVERS.
   Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this chapter, every driver of a
vehicle shall exercise due care to avoid colliding with any pedestrian upon any
roadway and shall give a warning by sounding a horn when necessary and shall
exercise proper precaution upon observing any child or any confused or
incapacitated person upon a roadway.
(Ord. 3639. Passed 3-19-65.)
442.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
422.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

442.05
   Motor vehicles in Stackhouse Park - see S.U. & P.S.
1062.13,
1062.14
   Location of uses involving motor vehicles - see P. & Z.
Ch. 1260
460.01 SPEED LIMITS GENERALLY.
   State traffic laws regulating the speed of vehicles upon all streets which
are a part of the State highway system shall be applicable upon all such
streets within the City. On all City streets not a part of the highway system
of the Commonwealth, no vehicle shall proceed at a rate of speed greater than
twenty-five miles per hour, unless otherwise posted.
(Ord. 3639. Passed 3-19-65.)
460.015 SPEED LIMITS IN ALLEYS.
   Speed limits for all City alleys (i.e. roadways named as "Places" and
"Courts") will be limited to a maximum of ten miles per hour.
(Ord. 4821. Passed 2-10-99.)
460.02 PROHIBITED OPERATION.
   No driver of any motor vehicle shall:
   (a)   Drive through any procession, such as funerals and parades, which are
properly indicated and identified as such;
   (b)   Drive through and upon an area which has been barricaded and
obstructed;
   (c)   Drive through a school safety patrol flag or area where school traffic
patrols have indicated, by flag or otherwise, that drivers of vehicles are to
stop;
   (d)   Operate the vehicle upon City streets under slippery conditions
created by snow and ice, without winter chains or treads, as the case may be;
or
   (e)   Open a car door into another lane of traffic.
(Ord. 3639. Passed 3-19-65.)
460.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
422.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
   Any person violating Section
460.01 is guilty of a summary offense and shall, upon conviction, be sentenced
to pay a fine of thirty-five dollars ($35.00). Any person exceeding the maximum
speed limit by more than five miles per hour shall pay an additional fine of
two dollars ($2.00) per mile for each mile in excess of five miles per hour
over the maximum speed limit.
(Ord. 4393. Passed 9-10-86.)
CHAPTER 462
Vehicle Equipment
462.01   Engine breaks.
 
462.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Vehicle equipment standards - see Vehicle Code §§ 4101 et seq.
   Lighting equipment - see Vehicle Code §§ 4301 et seq.
   Brakes - see Vehicle Code §§ 4501 et seq.
   Safety and antipollution equipment - see Vehicle Code §§ 4521 et seq.
   Vehicles for transportation of school children - see Vehicle Code §§ 4551 et
seq.
   Equipment of authorized and emergency vehicles - see Vehicle Code §§ 4571 et
seq.
   Child passenger protection - see Vehicle Code §§ 4581 et seq.
   Lights on parked vehicles - see TRAF.
482.19
462.01 ENGINE BREAKS.
   (a)   The operation of an engine break on a gasoline powered or diesel
powered motor vehicle not equipped with exhaust mufflers, or equipped with
defective or modified exhaust mufflers, so as to create excessive noise through
the use of such engine break, adversely affects the health, safety and welfare
of the residents of the City and, therefore, is hereby declared to be a
nuisance in fact.
   (b)   No person shall operate a gasoline powered or diesel powered motor
vehicle on the streets or alleys of the City, utilizing, in such operation, an
engine break, without exhaust mufflers, permitting excessive noise to be
created by such motor vehicle.
   (c)   This section shall not apply to emergency driving situations requiring
the utilization of an engine break to protect the safety and property of the
residents of the City, other motor vehicles and operators, pedestrians, and
operators and passengers of the motor vehicle involved in such emergency
situation.
(Ord. 4369. Passed 8-14-85.)
462.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating Section
462.01 shall be fined not more than three hundred dollars ($300.00) and costs
and, in default of the payment thereof for any reason other than indigency,
shall be imprisoned in the County Jail for not more than ten days.
(Ord. 4369. Passed 8-14-85.)

Commercial and Heavy Vehicles

464.001 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Operation" means the movement of vehicles on the surface of the
streets and roads of the City.
   (b)   "Posted" or "posting" means that signs will be placed on the roadways
and streets warning of the restrictions on the use of the roadways by certain
truck traffic.
   (c)   "Truck" means any vehicular device or means of equipment by which
persons or property may be transported upon the highways or streets, having a
gross vehicular weight of over 30,000 pounds.
   Other words and phrases used in this chapter shall have the meanings
respectively ascribed to them in the operating section of the Vehicle Code, as
supplemented and amended.
(Ord. 4770. Passed 3-12-97.)
464.01 WEIGHT LIMITS ON BRIDGES AND STREETS GENERALLY.
   Except as otherwise provided in this chapter or in the Vehicle Code, weight
limits on bridges and streets in the City shall be as posted on such bridges
and streets.
(Ord. 4393. Passed 9-10-86.)
464.02 WEIGHT LIMITS ON STREETS ENTERING CITY FROM OLD ROUTE 53, OLD ROUTE 56
AND ROUTE 219.
   The maximum weight of vehicles and loads entering the City by way of and
from Geistown Hill, Old Route 56, entering into Bedford Street; Frankstown
Road, Old Route 53, entering into East Main Street; and Prospect Hill, Route
219, entering into William Penn Avenue, is hereby established at 11,000 pounds
gross weight, when signs are erected giving notice thereof.
(Ord. 3638. Passed 3-19-65.)
464.03 TRUCKS PROHIBITED ON BANTELL STREET. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 464.03 was repealed by Ordinance 5353, passed May
31, 2023.)
464.04 DESIGNATION OF OTHER STREETS AND HIGHWAYS AS OFF-LIMITS TO TRUCKS.
(REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 464.04 was repealed by Ordinance 5353, passed May
31, 2023.)
464.05 ERECTION OF SIGNS; PROHIBITED OPERATION.
   (a)   Council hereby declares that it has, as authorized by the Vehicle
Code, caused, and may in the future cause, official signs to be erected on and
along certain public roads and highways of the City regulating the use of said
roads and the berms by certain types of vehicles.
   (b)   From and after the effective date of this section, no person shall
operate certain types of vehicles, as heretofore defined, on such roads or
streets in any manner contrary to the regulations so established, except as
hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 4770. Passed 3-12-97.)
464.06 PERMIT TO OPERATE TRUCKS ON PROHIBITED STREETS; REQUIREMENTS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 464.06 was repealed by Ordinance 5353, passed May
31, 2023.)
464.07 EXCEPTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to trucks making local
deliveries to residents and firms located on any public highway or street, nor
shall this chapter apply to residents or firms located on said restricted road
or street who or which own and/or operate trucks in excess of the weight
restriction set forth in Section
464.001, and who or which are required to use said roads or streets for access
to their residences or places of business.
(Ord. 4770. Passed 3-12-97; Ord. 5353. Passed 5-31-23.)
464.08 REVOCATION OF PERMITS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 464.08 was repealed by Ordinance 5353, passed May
31, 2023.)
464.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Any person driving a vehicle or combination upon a street exceeding
the weight limits established in Section
464.01 or
464.02 is guilty of a summary offense and shall, upon conviction, be fined
seventy-five dollars ($75.00) plus seventy-five dollars ($75.00) for each 500
pounds, or part thereof, in excess of 3,000 pounds over the maximum weight
permitted.
(Ord. 4393. Passed 9-10-86.)
   (b)   Except as provided in subsection (a) hereof, whoever violates any of
the provisions of this chapter shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
for each offense, together with costs of prosecution, and, in default of the
payment of such fine and costs, such person shall be imprisoned in the County
Jail for not more than thirty days.
(Ord. 4770. Passed 3-12-97.)
CHAPTER 466
Pedalcycles
466.01   Compliance required.
466.02   Registration.
466.03   License tags; registration cards.
466.04   Inspections.
466.05   Sales or transfers of ownership.
466.06   Dismantled or junked pedalcycles.
466.07   Destruction of serial numbers, license tags and registration cards.
466.08   Issuance of duplicate tags and registration cards.
466.09   Fees.
466.10   Expiration of licenses.
466.11   Impounding.
 
466.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Operation of pedalcycles - see Vehicle Code §§ 3501 et seq.
   Exemptions from lighting equipment requirements - see Vehicle Code § 4303
   Fees, registration, local regulation - see Vehicle Code § 6109
   Exemption from identification number requirement - see Vehicle Code § 7101
466.01 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   No person shall ride or use a pedalcycle upon any public street in the City
unless the same is inspected, licensed and registered as hereinafter provided.
(Ord. 4284. Passed 11-23-82.)
466.02 REGISTRATION.
   Upon the effective date of this chapter (Ordinance 4284, passed November 23,
1982), every owner of a pedalcycle shall list and register with the Bureau of
Police his or her name and address, the name of the manufacturer of the
pedalcycle and its number, style and general description, and shall present the
same for inspection as hereinafter set forth. If the owner of a pedalcycle is a
minor under the age of eighteen years, then the parent, guardian or person
having the care of such minor, or with whom he or she lives, shall make such
listing and registration on behalf of such minor.
(Ord. 4284. Passed 11-23-82.)
466.03 LICENSE TAGS; REGISTRATION CARDS.
   The Department of Police shall provide a license tag each year, together
with registration cards, which tags and cards shall nave numbers stamped
thereon in numerical order, beginning with number one, and indicating the year
for which the same are issued. Such tags shall be suitable for attachment upon
the frame of the pedalcycle. The Department shall issue to each owner one tag,
which shall be attached by the Department to the frame of the pedalcycle, and
shall issue a corresponding registration card to the owner upon payment of the
license fee and upon inspection approval hereinafter provided for. Such tag
shall remain attached to the pedalcycle for which it was issued during the
existence of such license. The Department shall also keep a record of such
registration and give a copy thereof to the Director/Chief of Police of the
City. The operator of the pedalcycle shall display his or her registration
card, or produce satisfactory proof that he or she has such registration card,
upon the demand of any officer of the Department.
(Ord. 4284. Passed 11-23-82.)
466.04 INSPECTIONS.
   Prior to the issuance of any license under this chapter, the Department of
Police shall inspect each pedalcycle to determine if it meets the minimum
requirements of the Vehicle Code, which requirements shall be a prerequisite to
the issuance of a license.
(Ord. 4284. Passed 11-23-82.)
466.05 SALES OR TRANSFERS OF OWNERSHIP.
   Every person who sells or transfers ownership of any pedalcycle shall report
such sale or transfer to the Department of Police. If such person has had his
or her pedalcycle licensed and registered, he or she shall also return to the
Department the registration card and license tag and shall furnish the
Department with the name and address of the person to whom such pedalcycle was
sold or transferred. Such report shall be made by the person selling or
transferring within five days of the date of such sale or transfer. The
purchaser or transferee of such pedalcycle shall apply immediately for a
registration card and license tag.
(Ord. 4284. Passed 11-23-82.)
466.06 DISMANTLED OR JUNKED PEDALCYCLES.
   Every person who dismantles, reduces to junk or takes out of operation any
pedalcycle, whether the same is registered or not, shall report such activity
to the Department of Police.
(Ord. 4284. Passed 11-23-82.)
466.07 DESTRUCTION OF SERIAL NUMBERS, LICENSE TAGS AND REGISTRATION CARDS.
   No person shall willfully or maliciously remove, destroy, mutilate or alter
the number on any pedalcycle frame, and no person shall remove, destroy,
mutilate or alter any license tag or registration card during the time in which
such license tag or registration card is operative. However, if any pedalcycle
does not have a serial number stamped on its frame, or if such number is
illegible, then the Department of Police shall stamp an identification number
on each frame of the pedalcycle.
(Ord. 4284. Passed 11-23-82.)
466.08 ISSUANCE OF DUPLICATE TAGS AND REGISTRATION CARDS.
   In the case of loss or destruction of a license tag or registration card, a
duplicate tag and/or registration card shall be issued, for a fee hereinafter
set forth, to the registered owner of the pedalcycle involved, provided that
such owner gives satisfactory proof of such loss or destruction, either by
affidavit or otherwise, to the Department of Police.
(Ord. 4284. Passed 11-23-82.)
466.09 FEES.
   The license fee for a registration card and tag required by this chapter
shall be fifty cents (50¢) for each pedalcycle and shall be paid to the
Department of Police at the time of registration, and a license fee of fifty
cents (50¢) shall be likewise paid for each renewal thereof. Upon application
for a duplicate tag and/or registration card, in accordance with Section
466.08, the owner shall pay to the Department a fee of fifty cents (50¢)for
such duplicate tag and fifty cents (50¢) for such duplicate registration card.
(Ord. 4284. Passed 11-23-82.)
466.10 EXPIRATION OF LICENSES.
   All license tags and registration cards shall expire on August 31, and all
pedalcycles shall be registered and retagged in a like manner, with payment of
the same fee as provided for originally, from August to August in each year.
(Ord. 4284. Passed 11-23-82.)
466.11 IMPOUNDING.
   (a)   If any pedalcycle is found in a street of the City without a license
identification tag as required by this chapter, or with a mutilated or altered
serial number or no serial number stamped on the frame of the pedalcycle, it
shall be prima-facie evidence that such pedalcycle is being operated without
proper registration and such pedalcycle shall be impounded as hereinafter set
forth.
   (b)   If the operator of any pedalcycle violates any of the provisions of
this chapter, such pedalcycle shall be immediately taken and impounded by the
Department of Police and shall be held by the Department for a period not
exceeding ten days, to be determined by the Director/Chief of Police. If any
pedalcycle is found in a condition described in subsection (a) hereof, the
Department shall take possession of such pedalcycle and hold the same until
proper ownership is proven.
(Ord. 4284. Passed 11-23-82.)
466.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
422.99 for general Traffic Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 468
Junked and/or Abandoned Motor Vehicles
468.01   Short title.
468.02   Administration and enforcement.
468.03   Definitions.
468.04   Parking or storage of abandoned motor vehicles prohibited.
468.05   Other prohibitions.
468.06   Exceptions.
468.07   Inspections, notices and enforcements.
 
468.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Abandoned vehicles generally - see Vehicle Code §§ 7301 et seq
   Impounding of motor vehicles - see TRAF.
422.02
   Obstruction of roadways by immobile vehicles - see TRAF.
440.04
   Commercial and heavy vehicles - see TRAF.
Ch. 464
   Unregistered or uninspected motor vehicles - see B. & H.
1428.04(b) (IPMC 302.8)
468.01 SHORT TITLE.
   This chapter shall be known and may be cited as the "Junked/Abandoned
Vehicle Ordinance of the City of Johnstown".
(Ord. 4773. Passed 6-11-97.)
468.02 ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT.
   This chapter will be administered and enforced by the Codes Enforcement
Department of the City of Johnstown. Said Department shall hereinafter be
referred to as "the Department".
(Ord. 4773. Passed 6-11-97; Ord. 5328. Passed 2-9-22.)
468.03 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purpose of administration and enforcement of this chapter, the
following definitions shall apply:
   (a)   Abandoned Motor Vehicle. A motor vehicle, or part thereof, which has
been voluntarily relinquished by its owner, with the intention of terminating
ownership, possession and control, without vesting ownership in any other
person.
   (b)   Garage. Any structure with four walls and a roof constructed for, or
capable of, the storage or parking of a motor vehicle.
   (c)   Junked Motor Vehicle. Any motor vehicle, or part thereof, outside a
fully enclosed building, which presents a hazard or danger to the public by
virtue of its state or condition of disrepair, or its wrecked, damaged or
dismantled condition, and which is unable to move under its own power or be
operated on a public street or highway.
   (d)   Motor Vehicle. Any self-propelled land vehicle which can be used for
towing or transporting people or materials, including, but not limited to,
automobiles, trucks, buses, motorhomes, motorized campers, motorcycles,
motorscooters, tractors, snowmobiles and dune buggies, and including trailers,
semi-trailers or other wheeled devices drawn thereby.
   (e)   Motor Vehicle Accessories. Any part or parts of any motor vehicle.
   (f)   Nuisance. Any condition or use of real property and/or any structures
thereon, and any condition or use of any mechanical device, including motor
vehicles, which shall constitute a threat, or a potential threat, to the
health, safety or welfare of the residents of the City.
   (g)   Owner. Any person having title, legal or equitable, whole or partial,
whether by deed, mortgage, lease or other contract, to real estate within the
City where motor vehicles are maintained, and any person having title, legal or
equitable, whole or partial, whether by lease, contract or other title
document, to any motor vehicle maintained within the City.
   (h)   Person. Every natural person, firm, partnership, association,
corporation, or other legal entity.
(Ord. 4773. Passed 6-11-97; Ord. 5328. Passed 2-9-22.)
468.04 PARKING OR STORAGE OF ABANDONED MOTOR VEHICLES PROHIBITED.
   (a)   No abandoned motor vehicle, as defined in this chapter, shall be
parked, stored or left to remain on any lot, tract or parcel of land or portion
thereof, whether occupied or unoccupied, improved or unimproved, within the
City of Johnstown, as further described in this section, unless permitted by
Section
468.06(a).
   (b)   A motor vehicle shall be presumed to be abandoned if it exhibits any
of the following circumstances and a code officer has investigated such
conditions below and has found the abandoned/junked vehicle to be in a nuisance
condition as defined in Section
468.05:
      (1)   An invalid registration plate;
      (2)   An invalid certificate of inspection;
      (3)   An identification number which cannot be ascertained;
      (4)   Is incapable of being moved under its own power;
      (5)   Has not been moved for a continuous period of more than 30 days; or
      (6)   Has remained on private property without the consent of the
property owner or person in control of the property for a period of more than
48 hours.
   (c)   To the extent that an abandoned motor vehicle may also be deemed or
classified as a junked motor vehicle, as defined in Section
468.03(c), that subsection shall control over this section.
(Ord. 4773. Passed 6-11-97; Ord. 5222. Passed 2-8-17.)
468.05 OTHER PROHIBITIONS.
   (a)   Motor Vehicle Nuisance Prohibited. No person, whether the owner of the
real estate upon which a motor vehicle nuisance is maintained or the owner of
such vehicle declared to be a nuisance, shall maintain a motor vehicle nuisance
upon open private or public grounds within the City of Johnstown. A motor
vehicle nuisance shall include any motor vehicle or trailer which is unable to
move under its own power and has any of the following physical defects:
      (1)   Broken windshields, mirrors, head-lamps, tail-lamps or other glass,
with sharp edges.
      (2)   One or more flat or open tires or tubes which could permit vermin
harborage.
      (3)   Storage or placement of the vehicle in an unbalanced condition,
such as on concrete blocks or other supports.
      (4)   Any body parts with sharp edges, including holes resulting from
rust.
      (5)   Missing tires resulting in unsafe suspension of the motor vehicle.
      (6)   Upholstery which is torn or open which could permit animal and/or
vermin harborage.
      (7)   Disassembled chassis parts apart from the motor vehicle, stored in
a disorderly fashion or loose in or on the vehicle.
      (8)   Broken vehicle frame suspended from the ground in an unstable
manner.
      (9)   Leaking of any fluids from the vehicle.
      (10)   Inoperable locking mechanism for doors or trunk.
      (11)   Damaged bumpers pulled away from the perimeter of the vehicle.
      (12)   Broken grill with protruding edges.
      (13)   Loose or damaged metal trim and clips.
      (14)   Such other defects which could threaten the health, safety and
welfare of the citizens of the City of Johnstown.
   (b)   Abandoned Motor Vehicles Prohibited. No person, whether the owner of
the real estate upon which an abandoned motor vehicle is maintained or the
owner of such vehicle abandoned, shall maintain an abandoned motor vehicle upon
open private or public grounds within the City of Johnstown.
   (c)   Storage Prohibited. No person owning or having custody of any junked
motor vehicle, abandoned motor vehicle or motor vehicle accessories, shall
store or permit any such vehicle or accessories to remain on any private
property within the City, where its presence constitutes a hazard, for a period
of more than ten days after receipt of a notice requiring such removal.
Further, no person owning any private property in the City shall store or
permit to remain any such vehicles or accessories on his or her property for
more than a like period. Such storage is declared to be a motor vehicle
nuisance and may be abated or removed and penalties imposed as provided in this
chapter. No person, after notification has been given, shall remove any junked
or abandoned motor vehicle or motor vehicle accessories from any private
property and move the same to any other private property upon which said
storage is not permitted or onto any public highway or other public property
for the purposes of storage.
(Ord. 4773. Passed 6-11-97.)
468.06 EXCEPTIONS.
   (a)   Permitted Storage. This chapter shall not apply to any motor vehicle
or motor vehicle accessories stored within an enclosed building, or on the
premises of a business enterprise operated in a lawful place and manner when
necessary to the operation of such business enterprise, or in a storage place
or depository maintained in a lawful place and manner, or to seasonal-use
vehicles, such as, snowmobiles, motorcycles, motor scooters and non-motorized
campers. As to junked motor vehicles or abandoned motor vehicles, such business
enterprises shall include automobile junkyards, but not auto repair shops. As
to motor vehicle accessories, junked motor vehicles and abandoned motor
vehicles, such business enterprises shall include automobile junkyards, and
auto repair and auto body shops, but shall not include automobile service
stations or tire, battery and accessory sales stores.
   (b)   Bona Fide Repair. Where storage or parking of one junked motor vehicle
on private property in other than a garage is for the purpose of bona fide
repair of such vehicle, and the owner or occupant of such property, or the
owner, operator or custodian of such motor vehicle, is not engaged in the
business of automobile repair, but intends to make such repair, such owner or
occupant of the property, or such owner, operator or custodian of such vehicle,
as the case may be, shall apply to the City for a permit for storage or parking
of one such vehicle in other than a garage during the course of its repair, for
a period of 30 days. At the discretion of the Department, a repair permit may
be renewed one time for an additional 30-day period, upon furnishing proof that
the repairs to the vehicle were actually begun during the initial permit
period, and that the delay in repairing the vehicle in the initial permit
period was not caused by the inaction of the owner, operator or custodian of
such vehicle.
(Ord. 4773. Passed 6-11-97.)
468.07 INSPECTIONS, NOTICES AND ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   Investigation of Premises. The Department, on routine inspection or
upon receipt of a complaint, may investigate a suspected junked motor vehicle,
an abandoned motor vehicle, or motor vehicle accessories, and record the make,
model, style and identification numbers in each situation.
   (b)   Inspection and Notice to Comply. The Department is hereby empowered,
upon inspection, if a non-compliance with the terms of this chapter shall
exist, to issue a written notice, served by registered or certified mail, upon
the owner of the premises and/or the owner of the motor vehicle nuisance being
maintained upon said premises, which notice shall specify the non-compliance
complained of, and shall require the owner, whether of the property where the
motor vehicle or accessories are stored or of the motor vehicle nuisance, to
remove or otherwise rectify the non-conformity, as set forth therein, within
ten days of the mailing of such notice. The City's Code Enforcement Officer
shall have the option and authority to extend this period where determined
necessary by extenuating circumstance, as determined in the Officer's
discretion, and in no event to exceed any period longer than 60 days unless
special approval has been granted by the City Manager, who will likewise be
required to notify City Council of any grant of special approval for an
extended period. If the owner of the property or of the motor vehicle nuisance
being maintained cannot be determined, the notice may be given by posting the
same conspicuously upon the offending premises and/or on the motor vehicle
nuisance.
   (c)   Authority to Remedy Non-Compliance. If the owner of the grounds upon
which the motor vehicle nuisance is maintained, and/or the owner of the motor
vehicle nuisance, fails to comply with the notice to abate the non-conformity,
of which notice is given, within the time limit prescribed, the City shall have
the authority to take measures to correct the non-compliance including, but not
limited to:
      (1)   Filing a complaint with the court for a violation of Section 302.8
of the International Property Maintenance Code; and/or
      (2)   Entering the property to impound the abandoned or junked vehicle at
the owners expense and/or expense of the property owner; and/or
      (3)   Collecting costs from the salvage contractor, plus 15% payable to
the City of Johnstown, at which time the salvage company will obtain ownership
of the abandoned or junked vehicle.
(Ord. 4773. Passed 6-11-97; Ord. 5222. Passed 2-8-17; Ord. 5328. Passed 2-9-
22.)
468.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

CHAPTER 480
Bureau of Parking
480.01   Establishment; responsibilities.

Ch. 1260
480.01 ESTABLISHMENT; RESPONSIBILITIES.
   There is hereby established in the Department of Public Works a Bureau of
Parking to be under the administrative control of the City Manager, acting
through the Director of Public Works. The Bureau shall be solely responsible
for the operation of all parking facilities and parking activities of the City,
including, but not limited to, the operation of all on and off-street parking
facilities, the installation of all street parking meters, the establishment of
rates for all parking meters and facilities and the establishment of zones and
rates pertinent thereto.
(Ord. 4668. Passed 7-13-94.)
480.02 GENERAL RESPONSIBILITIES.
   The Bureau of Parking shall be responsible for the administration and
direction of all parking operations, both on and off-street, for the
enforcement of all parking regulations and for the supervision of all personnel
with responsibilities related to parking.
(Ord. 4668. Passed 7-13-94.)
480.03 MONTHLY REPORTS.
   The Bureau of Parking shall account to the Director of Finance, not later
than the tenth day of each month, for all funds received during the preceding
calendar month.
(Ord. 4668. Passed 7-13-94.)
480.04 SPECIFIC DUTIES OF THE BUREAU; REGULATIONS.
   The official duties of the Bureau of Parking shall be as follows:
   (a)   The Bureau of Parking shall be responsible for the administration and
direction of all parking operations, both on and off street, for the
enforcement of all parking regulations and for the supervision of all personnel
with responsibilities related to parking.
   (b)   The Bureau of Parking shall conduct periodic surveys to collect facts
concerning traffic movements, parking needs, parking facilities and the
operation of parking garages.
   (c)   The Bureau of Parking shall prepare plans and make recommendations to
the City Manager and Council for the alleviation of parking problems and also
with respect to problems of City planning in its broader aspects.
   (d)   By and with the approval of the Director of Public Works, the Bureau
of Parking is hereby authorized to make regulations necessary to make effective
the provisions of the parking ordinances of the City and to make and enforce
temporary regulations to govern emergencies or special conditions. No person
shall violate any such regulation.
(Ord. 4668. Passed 7-13-94.)
480.05 DESIGNATION OF LOADING ZONES, BUS STOPS AND TAXICAB STANDS.
   (a)   The Manager of the Bureau of Parking is hereby authorized to determine
the location of passenger zones and freight loading zones and to place and
maintain thereat appropriate signs indicating the same and the hours during
which they may be lawfully used for their intended purposes. However, he or she
shall not designate such a zone unless a person makes an application for a
permit for such a zone and for proper signs to indicate such zone and unless
there is collected in advance or with the application the required fee under
Section
482.17.
   (b)   The Manager is hereby authorized and required to establish bus stops,
taxicab stands and stands for common carrier motor vehicles on such public
streets, in such places and in such a manner as are determined to be of
greatest benefit and convenience to the public. Every such bus stop, taxicab
stand or other stand shall be designated by appropriate signs to be furnished
by the common carrier or other applicant for such stops or stands.
(Ord. 4320. Passed 11-22-83.)
480.06 PARKING REVENUE FUND.
   There is hereby established a special fund in the accounting records of the
City, to be designated the Parking Revenue Fund, which Fund shall be opened and
maintained by the City in one or more authorized depositories and which Fund
shall be kept separate and distinct from all other accounts of the City and
applied solely for the purposes stated in Section
480.10(d). There shall be credited to the Parking Revenue Fund all moneys
received by the City pursuant to Chapters
480 through 484 of this Traffic Code.
(Ord. 4320. Passed 11-22-83.)
480.07 RECORDS OF PARKING VIOLATIONS.
   (a)   The Bureau of Parking shall keep a record of all violations of the
parking ordinances of the City or of the Vehicle Code of which any person has
been charged, together with the record of the final disposition of all such
alleged offenses. Such record shall be so maintained as to show all types of
violations and the total of each. Such record shall be maintained for a five-
year period, and from that time on, the record shall be maintained complete for
at least the most recent five-year period.
   (b)   All such records and reports shall be public records.
   (c)   The Bureau of Parking shall be assigned to keep the following records
and perform the following duties:
      (1)   The Bureau shall count the stubs and enter the numbers and quantity
of the stubs on the appropriate line on the weekly record to be kept as
hereinafter provided.
      (2)   The Bureau shall record on the weekly record all parking tickets
issued each day. Each ticket shall be recorded in a permanent book, to be known
as the Record of Parking Citations, showing the ticket number, the date of
issuance, the officer's name and number, the license number of the vehicle
involved and the date of the charge.
      (3)   The Director of Finance shall issue a receipt, in duplicate, for
each payment of a parking ticket, and the receipt shall show the number of the
ticket being paid. Individual entries shall be made in the Record of Parking
Citations from the duplicate receipts showing the name of the person charged,
his or her address, the amount paid, the date settled and the receipt number.
      (4)   No parking ticket, once issued, shall be dismissed without the
approval and consent of the Manager of the Bureau. A dismissal memorandum shall
be prepared daily by the Manager in quadruplicate, listing thereon the number
of the ticket dismissed. Individual entries shall be made in the Record of
Parking Citations showing the dismissal and the date of dismissal.
      (5)   A daily report of tickets shall be prepared by the Bureau of
Parking in quadruplicate and shall contain the following information: the
balance at the beginning of the day, the number of tickets issued, the cash
received, the number of dismissals, the balance at the end of the day and the
costs collected.
      (6)   The Bureau shall prepare a monthly report of tickets in
quadruplicate containing the following information: the balance at the end of
the month and at the beginning of the month, tickets issued, cash received, the
number of dismissals and the costs collected.
      (7)   Copies of dismissal memorandums, daily reports and monthly reports
shall be given to the City Manager, the Director of Public Works and the
Director of Finance.
      (8)   A weekly record of tickets shall be kept by the Bureau and shall
contain the following information: the number of each officer issuing the
tickets and the numbers and quantity of tickets issued by each officer each day
of the week.
      (9)   The permanent Record of Parking Citations shall disclose the final
disposition of each ticket.
      (10)   Ticket stubs may be destroyed at the expiration of thirty days
after the stubs are posted on the records to be kept by the Bureau as herein
provided, except that those tickets which have not been paid or which are being
litigated shall not be destroyed and shall be maintained on file.
      (11)   The Bureau shall provide monthly reports to the City Manager and
Council on the financial and operational status of the parking program.
(Ord. 4668. Passed 7-13-94.)
480.08 WAIVER SCHEDULES.
   The District Magistrate who hears parking cases shall designate the
specified offenses under the parking ordinances of the City and the State
traffic laws in respect to which payments of fines may be accepted by the City
in satisfaction thereof and shall specify by suitable schedules the amount of
such fines for first, second and subsequent offenses, provided that such fines
are within the limits specified by law or ordinance, and shall further specify
what number of such offenses shall require an appearance before the District
Magistrate.
(Ord. 4320. Passed 11-22-83.)
480.09 OPTION TO PAY WAIVER FINE OR ENTER NOT GUILTY PLEA.
   Any person charged with an offense for which payment of a fine may be made
to the Bureau of Parking shall have the option of paying such fine at the
office of the Director of Finance within the time specified on the notice of
arrest, upon entering a plea of guilty and upon waiving appearance in court, or
may deposit the required bail and enter a plea of not guilty, in which case he
or she shall be entitled to a trial as authorized by law. The payment of a fine
to the City shall be deemed an acknowledgment of conviction of the alleged
offense and the Director of Finance, upon accepting the prescribed fine, shall
issue one receipt to the violator acknowledging payment thereof.
(Ord. 4668. Passed 7-13-94.)
480.10 COLLECTION AND USE OF PROCEEDS.
   (a)   All parking meter receipts, fines, penalties, fees and other charges
provided for in Chapters
480 through 484 of this Traffic Code are levied and assessed to cover the
regulation and control of parking upon public streets; the cost of new parking
meters and their installation, inspection, supervision, operation, repair and
maintenance; the control and use of parking spaces; the regulation of parking
of vehicles in parking meter zones; and the cost of acquiring, establishing,
improving, maintaining and operating public off-street parking facilities,
including those facilities now or hereafter leased by the City from the Parking
Authority.
   (b)   All parking meter and parking garage receipts and all other moneys
which come into the possession of the Bureau of Parking under Chapters
480 through 484 shall be deposited daily by him or her or his or her authorized
agent in a special account to be designated the Parking Revenue Fund.
   (c)   All other moneys, including, but not limited to, parking meter
receipts, fines, penalties, fees and other charges provided for in Chapters
480 through 484, which may come into the possession of duly authorized agents
or bureaus of the City, shall be deposited daily with the Director of Finance
who shall make daily deposits thereof, together with all funds received
directly by the Director of Finance under and pursuant to Chapters
480 through 484, to the credit of the Parking Revenue Fund. All such agents or
bureaus shall account to the Director of Finance and the Bureau of Parking not
later than the tenth day of each month for all funds received during the
preceding calendar month. The Director of Finance shall further account to the
Bureau for all funds received by him or her independently as a result of the
enforcement of Chapters
480 through 484 in the same manner.
   (d)   All moneys credited to the Parking Revenue Fund shall be used for the
following purposes and no other:
      (1)   To pay the operating expenses of parking facilities, including the
cost of enforcement and collection of all fees and fines pursuant to Chapters
480 through
484;
      (2)   To pay the Johnstown Parking Authority the lease rental payments
and other payments required pursuant to that certain Agreement of Lease, dated
April 1, 1970, between the City and the Authority, and all Agreements of Lease
supplemental thereto; and
      (3)   To pay the City General Revenue Fund all proceeds in excess of
those required for purposes outlined in paragraphs (d)(1) and (2) hereof.
(Ord. 4668. Passed 7-13-94.)
480.11 REFUND OF ERRONEOUSLY PAID FINES.
   (a)   Any person who, by error or mistake, pays the fine for any parking
violation more than once shall be entitled to a refund of the overpayment.
   (b)   The Bureau of Parking shall prepare for the signature of the City
Manager an application for a refund of the overpayment.
   (c)   Upon receipt of such application, the City Manager or the City Clerk
shall make a recommendation to Council for authorization to make such refund.
(Ord. 4668. Passed 7-13-94.)
480.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any provision of this chapter is guilty of a summary
offense and shall, upon conviction, be sentenced to pay a fine of not more than
fifteen dollars ($15.00).
(Ord. 4393. Passed 9-10-86.)
