waste pipe or vent pipe is disconnected or abandoned, all openings shall be
sealed tight.
(Ord. 3309. Passed 8-19-58.)

International Property Maintenance Code
EDITOR'S NOTE: This chapter, previously titled "BOCA National Property

   (b)   "Code Official" means the Codes Administrator or his or her authorized

1428.04 AMENDMENTS.
   (a)   Deletions. The following section of the International Property
Maintenance Code, as adopted herein, is hereby deleted in its entirety:
   SECTION 111, MEANS OF APPEAL.
   303.19 APPROVED MEANS OF EGRESS.
   (b)   Revisions. The following sections of the International Property
Maintenance Code, as adopted herein, are hereby revised to read as follows:
      Section 304.14 Insect screens. During the period form May 1 through
September 30, every door, window and outside opening required for ventilation
of habitable rooms, food preparation areas, food service areas, or any areas
where products to be included or utilized in food for human consumption are
processed, manufactured, packaged or stored, shall be supplied with approved
tightly fitting screens of not less than 16 mesh per inch (12 mesh per 25 mm)
and every swinging door shall have a self-closing device in good working
condition.
      Exception: Screens shall not be required where other approved means such
as air curtains or insect repellant fans are employed.
      Section 602.3 Heat supply. Every owner and operator of any building who
rents, leases or lets one or more dwelling unit, rooming unit, dormitory or
guestroom on terms, either expressed or implied, to furnish heat to occupants
thereof shall supply heat during the period from September 15, to April 15 to
maintain a temperature of not less than 68 degrees F in all habitable rooms,
bathrooms and toilet rooms.
(Ord. 4806. Passed 8-19-98; Ord. 5089. Passed 7-13-12.)
      Section 602.4 Occupiable work spaces. Indoor occupiable work spaces shall
be supplied with heat during the period from September 15 to April 15 to
maintain a temperature not less than 68 degrees F during the period the spaces
are occupied.
(Ord. 4806. Passed 8-19-98; Ord. 5089. Passed 7-13-12.)
   (c)   Additions. The following sections are hereby added to the
International Property Maintenance Code, as adopted herein.
      Section 702.5 Number of Exists:  In nonresidential buildings, every
occupied story more than six stories above grade shall be provided with not
less than two independent exists. In residential buildings, every story
exceeding two stories above grade shall be provided with not less than two
independent exists. In stories where more than one exist is required, all
occupants shall have access to at lease two exists. Every occupied story which
is both totally below grade and greater than 2,000 square feet (186 m2) shall
be provided with not less than two independent exists.
      Exceptions: A single exist is acceptable under any one of the following
conditions:
      1.   Where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic
sprinkler system and an automatic fire detection system with smoke detectors
located in all corridors, lobbies and common areas.
      2.   Where the building is equipped throughout with an automatic fire
detection system and the exit is an approved smokeproof enclosure or
pressurized stair-way.
      3.   Where an existing fire escape conforming to the building code is
provided in addition to the single exist.
      4.   Where permitted by the building code.
(Ord. 4806. Passed 8-19-98.)
      Section 702.6 Approved means of egress: Every dwelling unit shall have
one or more approved means of egress, with a minimum head room of six feet, six
inches, leading to safe and open space at ground level, and every dwelling unit
in a multiple dwelling shall have immediate access to two or more approved
means of egress, with a minimum head room of six feet, six inches, leading to
safe and open space at ground level.
(Ord. 4673. Passed 7-13-94; Ord. 4717. Passed 3-22-95; Ord. 4974. Passed 10-12-
05.)
1428.05 PENDING LITIGATION.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to affect any suit or proceeding

(Ord. 4136. Passed 2-28-79; Ord. 4974. Passed 10-12-05.)
1428.06 OBSTRUCTING INSPECTIONS.
   No owner, occupant or other person in charge of a dwelling unit, rooming
unit or any residential structure covered by the International Property
Maintenance Code shall refuse, impede, inhibit, interfere with, restrict or
obstruct entry and free access to every part of the structure where inspection
is sought by the Building Inspectors and Housing Inspectors of the City. In the
case of violations of this section, the Codes Administrator may seek, in a
court of competent jurisdiction, an order that such owner, occupant or other
person in charge cease and desist, with such interference. Such remedy shall be
in addition to the penalty provided in Section
1428.99 .
(Ord. 4974. Passed 10-12-05.)

   No person shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter, or fail to

certificate issued under this chapter.
(Ord. 4397. Passed 9-10-86; Ord. 4974. Passed 10-12-05.)

   Notwithstanding any provision of the International Property Maintenance Code

   (a)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of the

1428.99 PENALTY.
   The City may institute proceedings under this chapter by the issuance of a
“notice of violation letter,” assessing a civil penalty of seventy-five dollars
($75.00) for the first offense and provide the parties in violation of said
chapter the opportunity to abate the violation. If after ten (10) business days
and neither was the fine paid nor the violation abated, the City shall issue a
second “notice of violation letter” assessing a civil penalty in the amount of
one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). If abatement of property violations does
not occur after the second notice of violation and another ten (10) business
days have passed, the City Manager and/or his designee may enlist the aid of a
collections agency to collect unpaid violation penalties; City employees may
also enter the property to remediate the violation at the expense of the
property owner. The City, through its City Manager, Code Enforcement Officer
and/or Solicitor, is authorized to file a non-traffic criminal citation
pursuant to the Rule of Criminal Procedure 4403 as a summary offense punishable
by up to two thousand five hundred dollar ($2,500.00) fine and/or 90 days of
imprisonment. Pursuant to the Rule of Criminal Procedure 4462(b) the City,
through its Solicitor, may prosecute any de novo summary appeal of any
conviction of such violations as approved by the District Attorney's Office,
Cambria County, Pennsylvania via written correspondence on June 22, 2017. If no
specific penalty is provided then Section
202.99 for general code violations.
(Ord. 5144. Passed 3-5-14; Ord. 5238. Passed 9-13-17; Ord. 5334. Passed 4-20-
22; Ord. 5353. Passed 5-31-23.)

1430.03 DEFINITIONS.

   (a)   "Building Official" means the Code Administrator or his or her
authorized representative.
   (b)   "Name of Jurisdiction" means the City of Johnstown.
(Ord. 4975. Passed 10-12-05.)
1430.04 PENDING LITIGATION.
   Nothing in this chapter shall be construed to affect any suit or proceeding
now pending in any court or any right acquired or liability incurred, or any
cause of action accrued or exiting, under any action or ordinance repealed
hereby. No right or remedy of any character shall be lost, impaired or affected
by this chapter.
(Ord. 4975. Passed 10-12-05.)
1430.05 VIOLATIONS GENERALLY.
   No person shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter, or fail to
comply with any of the requirements thereof, or violate or fail to comply with
an approved plan or directive of the Codes Administrator or with a permit or
certificate issued under this chapter.
(Ord. 4975. Passed 10-12-05.)
1430.06 CONFLICT OF LAWS.
   Notwithstanding any provision of the International Residential Code to the
contrary:
   (a)   In the event of a conflict between the provisions of the International
Residential Code, as adopted in Section
1430.01 , and a provision of any local ordinance, resolution, rule or
regulation, the local ordinance, resolution, rule or regulation shall control.
   (b)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of such Code
and a provision of any State law, rule or regulation, the State law, rule or
regulation shall control.
   (c)   In the event of a conflict between any of the provisions of such Code
and a provision of any other technical code adopted by reference by the City,
the stricter or higher standard shall control.
(Ord. 4975. Passed 10-12-05.)
1430.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Code Violation Correction & Response Unit. The City Department of
Community & Economic Development and/or the Department of Codes & Permits, with
the addition of this section shall institute and enforce all provisions as
follows:
      (1)   "A Codes Violation Correction & Response Unit" is created and
authorized.
      (2)   The "Unit" and employees assigned to said unit shall work under the
direction of the City Manager through the Director of Codes & Permits and/or
Director of Community & Economic Development.
      (3)   Unit shall be dispatched to properties which have failed to correct
and/or abate code violations as per local property maintenance or any other
adopted ordinances.
      (4)   A minimum/mandatory charge shall be issued against the registered
property owners. The fee shall be established by ordinance of City Council and
amended from time to time. These fees, along with the applicable code
violations, would be filed with the District Courts, if not paid within ten
days of the "Code Violation Correction & Response Unit" taking corrective
actions.
      (5)   Code violations would be required to be filed with the District
Court as continuing violations not abated, every twenty days until full
abatement and compliance has been met.
      (6)   Additional charges for materials, supplies and equipment required
in situation requiring enclosing, securing units with open access and determine
to be unsafe and hazardous conditions present.
      (7)   All monies collected for work performed by the City's "Code
Violation Correction & Response Unit" shall be deposited and credited to
established CDBG revenue line items such as: Reimbursement-"Code Violation
Correction & Response Unit". Fines assessed by the district courts and
collected, would be credited in the same manner to be determined by the City
Manager.
      (8)   And all such violations "shall" result in charges being filed, and
with no discretion permitted.
      (9)   Provision as contained in this section shall be given prior to the
"Codes Violation Correction & Response Unit" being dispatched to said
properties:
         A.   Given a written notice citing violations, and be given a period
of fifteen days to correct or abate said violations.
         B.   The Code Enforcement Department may grant one fifteen day
extension of time to permit compliance with Building and Housing Standards
after an onsite inspection to determine if violations are being corrected.
   (b)   Penalty. All violations as listed under Part 14 titled: Building and
Housing Code shall be:
      (1)   Given a written notice citing violations, and be given a period of
fifteen days to correct or abate said violations.
      (2)   The Code Enforcement Department may grant one fifteen day extension
of time to permit compliance with Building and Housing Standards after an
onsite inspection to determine if violations are being corrected.
      (3)   All violation of Part 14 of the Building and Housing Code not
corrected in the time stipulated, shall result in charges filed with the
district courts, and upon conviction shall be fined not less the five hundred
dollars ($500.00).
      (4)   Any such non-compliance is a continuing violation for each day the
violation remains, and the same charges shall be filed with the district courts
by the tenth day after the previous filing.
      (5)   Other than the granting of one fifteen day extension, City Codes
and other City personnel with authority under this section, shall have no
discretion in the filing of charges under this section, and failure to subject
such personnel to provisions under Section
202.99, General Code Penalty; Complicity; Equitable Remedies, and possible
discharge from employment with the City of Johnstown.
(Ord. 4975. Passed 10-12-05; Ord. 5054. Passed 2-24-10; Ord. 5353. Passed 5-31-
23.)

1440.01 CODES ENFORCED.
   The term "applicable codes and ordinances," as referred to in this and other
chapters of this Building and Housing Code, means:
   (a)   The International Building Code, as adopted in
Chapter 1420  of this Building and Housing Code;
   (b)   The International Plumbing Code, as adopted in
Chapter 1422;
   (c)   The National Electrical Code, as adopted in
Chapter 1424;
   (d)   The International Mechanical Code, as adopted in
Chapter 1426 ; and
   (e)   The International Property Maintenance Code, as adopted in
Chapter 1428 .
(Ord. 5290. Passed 6-10-20.)
1440.02 SCOPE OF AUTHORITY.
   The Bureau of Codes Enforcement and Health of the Department of Community
and Economic Development shall be headed by the Codes Administrator, who shall
administer and enforce the provisions of all applicable codes and ordinances
referred to in Section
1440.01.
(Ord. 4153. Passed 9-26-79.)
1440.03 INSPECTIONS.
   The Codes Administrator shall, when he or she deems it necessary to order
inspections of any conditions by any other department, arrange for the
inspections to be performed in such a manner that the owner or occupant of a
building shall not be subject to visits by numerous inspectors or to multiple
or conflicting orders.
(Ord. 4153. Passed 9-26-79.)
1440.04 ORDERS FOR CORRECTION OF VIOLATIONS.
   No order for the correction of a violation under the applicable codes and
ordinances shall be issued without the approval of the Codes Administrator. The
Codes Administrator shall, before issuing any such order, determine that it has
the concurrence of any other department or official of the Municipality
concerned with any matters involved in the case in question.
(Ord. 4153. Passed 9-26-79.)
1440.05 STOP WORK ORDERS.
   No person shall continue any work in or about a building after having been
served with a stop work order, except such work as he or she is directed to
perform in removing a violation or unsafe condition.
(Ord. 4153. Passed 9-26-79.)
1440.06 PENDING PROCEEDINGS.
   Nothing in this chapter or in the applicable codes and ordinances shall be
construed to affect any suit or proceeding now pending in any court, or any
rights acquired or liability incurred, or any cause of action accrued or
existing, under any act or ordinance repealed hereby. No right or remedy of any
kind shall be lost, impaired or affected by this chapter.
(Ord. 4153. Passed 9-26-79.)
1440.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

1442.01 BUILDING CODE OFFICIAL.
   The Building Code Official, before recommending the issuance of a permit,
shall examine or cause to be examined all buildings, structures and sites for
which a building permit application has been filed, and shall conduct
inspections, maintain records and perform such other duties as provided for
under this Building and Housing Code.
(Ord. 4153. Passed 9-26-79; Ord. 5182. Passed 9-9-15.)
1442.02 CODE ENFORCEMENT OFFICER.
   (a)   Duties. Code Enforcement Officers of the City shall make or cause to
be made inspections to determine the conditions of one and two-family
dwellings, dwelling units, multifamily dwellings, rooming houses and premises
in order to safeguard the safety, morals and welfare of the public, in
accordance with applicable codes and ordinances of the City.
   (b)   Right of Entry. The Officers are hereby authorized to enter any one
and two-family dwelling, dwelling unit, multifamily dwelling, rooming house or
other building or premises at any reasonable time for the purpose of performing
their duties under the applicable codes and ordinances of the City.
(Ord. 4153. Passed 9-26-79; Ord. 5182. Passed 9-9-15.)
1442.03 OTHER INSPECTIONS. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Section 1442.03 was repealed by Ordinance 5182, passed
September 9, 2015.)
1442.04 FEES.
   The Director of Finance shall collect all building permit fees based on a
fee schedule adopted by ordinance of City Council and amended from time to
time. The Building Code Official shall periodically review existing fees for
applicable codes and ordinances of the City.
      The fees shall include the required surcharge fee to the State of
Pennsylvania per Act 13 of the Uniform Construction Code.
      The fees above include two compliance inspections to be completed by the
Building Code Official. Any additional inspections will be a separate cost of
twenty dollars ($20.00) per inspection. The UCC inspections are a separate cost
and separate inspection outside of the compliance inspection.
      In addition, for building projects which require a building permit in
accordance with Section
1202 of these Codified Ordinances, that were started without a building permit,
the cost shall be double that shown in the above schedule. Three violations in
starting without a building permit will result in the immediate one year
suspension of the contractor to receive a contractor's license or building
permit through the City of Johnstown.
   (c)   Demolition. The fee for demolition of a building or structure shall
include fees for the sewer cap, any additional permit and inspection fees
required, and the required surcharge fee to the State of Pennsylvania per Act
13 of the Uniform Construction Code.
      In addition, for demolition projects which require a demolition permit in
accordance with Section
1460.01, that were started without a demolition permit, the cost shall be
doubled that shown in the above schedule. Three violations in starting without
a building permit will result in the immediate one year suspension of the
contractor to receive a contractor's license or building permit through the
City of Johnstown.
   (d)   Moving of Building. The fee for moving of buildings is sixty-five
dollars ($65.00), plus the actual cost of any City services required.
   (e)   Plumbing. Fixture fees are set by the International Plumbing Code, as
adopted and in
Chapter 1422 .
   (f)   Occupancy Certificate. A fee shall be charged for each residential
certificate of occupancy issued by the Building Code Official. A fee shall be
charged for each commercial certificate of occupancy issued by the Building
Code Official. The fees shall be established by ordinance of City Council and
amended from time to time.
   (g)   Plan Review. The fee for a required plan review shall be determined by
the City's third party agency agreement.
   (h)   Residential Inspection shall be completed by either the Building Code
Official or the City’s third party agency and shall consist of the following:
      (1)   Superior Wall System-
         Footing – Prior to installing stone bed & setting walls.
         Foundation – After first floor joist and deck are set, prior to
backfill.
      (2)   Concrete/Masonry System-
         Footing- Prior to pouring concrete.
         Foundation – Prior to backfilling.
      (3)   Aboveground Plumbing – Prior to covering, drainage & water line
test required.
      (4)   Electrical Rough-In – Prior to covering, all wiring & boxes shall
be installed. All grounds shall be made for this inspection.
      (5)   Mechanical Rough-In – Prior to covering. Gas piping test is
required.
      (6)   Framing – Prior to insulation or covering.
      (7)   Electrical Final – All equipment, fixtures, and devices shall be
functional.
      (8)   Mechanical Final – All equipment shall be set and functional.
      (9)   Plumbing Final – All equipment and fixtures shall be set and
functional.
      (10)   Final Inspection – Prior to any use or occupancy.
            The fees for the above inspections shall be determined by the
City’s Third Party Agency Agreement.
   (i)   Commercial Inspections shall consist of the following:
      (1)   Footings – Prior to pouring concrete footings and pier boxes. Rebar
and forms shall be installed.
      (2)   Foundations – Prior to backfilling below grade and prior to pouring
five foot maximum grout lift or bond beam.
      (3)   Underground Fire Main – Prior to covering or pouring thrust blocks.
200 PSI test required.
      (4)   Underground Plumbing – Prior to covering, drainage lines test
required.
      (5)   Underground Electrical – Prior to covering.
      (6)   Aboveground Plumbing – Prior to covering, water and drainage line
test required.
      (7)   Electrical Rough-In – Prior to covering, all boxes shall be
installed and all grounds shall be made.
      (8)   Mechanical Rough-In – Prior to covering. Gas piping requires an air
test.
      (9)   Fire Alarm Rough-In – Prior to covering conductors.
      (10)   Framing – Prior to installation. Steel connections report
required.
      (11)   Aboveground Fire Sprinkler Rough-In – Prior to installing ceiling.
200 PSI test required.
      (12)   Electrical Final – All equipment, fixtures, and devices. Shall
include a test of the emergency lighting.
      (13)   Mechanical Final – All equipment shall be functional. Kitchen
exhaust system test required.
      (14)   Plumbing Final – All equipment and fixtures shall be functional.
Potable water certificate required.
      (15)   Final Fire Alarm/Fire Sprinkler – Inspector’s test and main drain
flow with the activation of all alarm initiation devices and supervisory
devices.
      (16)   Final – Prior to any use or occupancy. Shall include a test of the
stage curtain.
            The fees for the above inspections shall be determined by the
City’s Third Party Agency Agreement.
(Ord. 4701. Passed 12-21-94.; Ord. 4837. Passed 12-8-99; Ord. 4869. Passed 1-
10-01; Ord. 4979. Passed 10-12-05; Ord. 5182. Passed 9-9-15; Ord. 5353. Passed
5-31-23.)
1442.05 SALE OF PROPERTY; CERTIFICATES REQUIRED.
   The City hereby enacts all the provisions of the Act of July 27, 1955 (P.L.
288, No. 104), as amended by Act 24A of November, 1973, which makes it unlawful
for owners of certain properties in the City to sell or agree to sell such
properties without first delivering to the purchaser a certification of the
district classification and a certification disclosing any notice of an
uncorrected violation of any housing, building, safety or fire code or
ordinance, and which requires such owners to insert in any agreement of sale of
such property a statement concerning zoning classification, legality of the use
of such property and uncorrected violations of housing, building, safety or
fire codes or ordinances.
(Ord. 3982. Passed 11-27-73.)

1464.32
1444.01 CODE HEARING BOARD.
   (a)   Establishment. There is hereby established a Code Hearing Board, to be
appointed by Council and to consist of at least five members, who shall serve
without compensation, but who may be reimbursed for necessary reasonable
expenses. Their terms of office shall be for three years, except for those
first appointed, whose terms shall be so fixed that the term of office of at
least one member expires each year. An appointment to fill a vacancy shall be
only for the unexpired portion of the term.
   (b)   Qualifications of Board Members. Two members of the Board shall be
knowledgeable in building construction, two members shall be knowledgeable in
property management and real estate and one member shall be a home owner within
the City. All members shall be residents of the City.
   (c)   Powers and Duties. The Board shall have the following powers and
duties:
      (1)   Interpretation. On appeal from a determination of the Codes
Administrator or his or her authorized representative, or on request of any
Municipal official, the Board shall decide any question involving the
interpretation of this Building and Housing Code.
      (2)   Variances. The Board may grant a variance from the strict
application of this Building and Housing Code. Such a variance may be granted
only in those cases where a strict interpretation of this Building and Housing
Code would result in practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship and where the
public health and safety will not be jeopardized by the granting of such
variance.
      (3)   Appeals. The Board shall hear all appeals made to it and, depending
on its findings, shall decide whether or not to affirm or overrule the decision
appealed.
(Ord. 4153. Passed 9-26-79.)
1444.02 AUTHORITY TO REQUEST VARIANCES AND TO APPEAL.
   Any person desiring a variance or aggrieved by a decision of the Codes
Administrator or his or her authorized representative charged with the
administration and enforcement of this Building and Housing Code may make his
or her request for the variance, or take an appeal, to the Code Hearing Board.
All appeals shall be made in writing, stating the grounds upon which the appeal
is based, and shall be transmitted to the office of the Codes Administrator. An
appeal must be taken within fifteen days of the action or of the receipt of
written notice of any decision or ruling which is being appealed.
(Ord. 4153. Passed 9-26-79.)
1444.03 HEARINGS AND DECISIONS ON VARIANCES AND APPEALS.
   (a)   Public Hearing. The Code Hearing Board shall meet and conduct a
hearing within thirty days of the receipt of an appeal or a request for a
variance. All hearings shall be public and all persons whose interest may be
affected shall be given an opportunity to be heard. A record shall be kept of
all evidence and testimony presented at the hearing.
   (b)   Decision of Board. All decisions of the Board shall be in writing and
a copy of each decision shall be sent to the applicant and to the Codes
Administrator. The Board shall also retain in its files a copy of each
decision, which files shall be available for inspection by the public. Such
decision shall set forth fully the reasons for the decision of the Board and
the findings of facts on which the decision was based. The Board shall make an
order based on its decision and the Codes Administrator shall take immediate
action to carry out such order.
(Ord. 4153. Passed 9-26-79.)
1444.04 APPEALS FROM DECISIONS OF CODE HEARING BOARD.
   Any person aggrieved by a final order or decision of the Code Hearing Board
may appeal such order or decision, within thirty days, to the Court of Common
Pleas in accordance with, as far as practical, the Rules of Civil Procedure of
the Supreme Court regarding appeals from administrative agencies.
(Ord. 4153. Passed 9-26-79.)
1444.05 REPORTS TO COUNCIL.
   The Code Hearing Board shall report to Council periodically, at intervals of
not less than twelve months, summarizing the Board's activities of the twelve-
month period. The Board may also submit to the City Manager advisory reports
recommending changes and modifications in this Building and Housing Code or in
other applicable codes and ordinances.
(Ord. 4673. Passed 7-13-94.)

Ch. 1448
1446.01 ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP; FUNCTION; RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   There is hereby established in and for the City a Board of Plumbing
Examiners, to consist of one member of the Board of Health, one Plumbing
Inspector, and two competent plumbers in no way connected to the City
Government, and all of whom shall be appointed by the City Manager. The Board
shall examine all applicants for licenses and certificates under this chapter.
The Board is hereby authorized to make all reasonable rules, regulations and
examinations, subject to the approval of the Director of Public Works.
(Ord. 4673. Passed 7-13-94; Ord. 5290. Passed 6-10-20.)
1446.02 MEETINGS.
   Meetings of the Board of Plumbing Examiners shall be held semiannually in
the City Hall. Meetings shall be held at 9:00 a.m. on the first Monday of March
and September. Special meetings may be called at other times by the Chairperson
of the Board. Persons interested in such special meetings will be notified of
the same.
(Ord. 20. Passed 3-17-14.)
1446.03 APPLICATIONS FOR EXAMINATIONS.
   (a)   Applications for examinations must be filed with the Board of Health.
   (b)   The applicant must state, in his or her own writing and over his or
her own signature, his or her full name and place of residence, and, if a
member of a firm, company or corporation, the name, style or title of the same,
the title of any office held in such firm, company or corporation, and its
place of business. If the applicant is a journeyman, he or she must also give
the name and place of business of his or her employer.
(Ord. 20. Passed 3-17-14.)
1446.04 METHOD OF EXAMINATION.
   Examinations shall consist of a practical demonstration, or written answers
to not less than fifty printed or typewritten questions, and written replies to
questions asked orally regarding cuts or drawings made upon paper or a
blackboard, which questions shall be of such character as to fairly test the
fitness and qualifications of the applicant to engage in the trade or business
of plumbing. Applicants for a master plumbers certificate shall be examined in
the higher branches of the profession.
(Ord. 20. Passed 3-17-14.)
1446.05 PASSING GRADE.
   The applicant must have a rating of at least seventy-five percent on his or
her examination to entitle him or her to a license and certificate of
competency.
(Ord. 20. Passed 3-17-14.)
1446.06 FALSIFICATION.
   Falsification or fraud in an application or examination shall be cause for
dismissal of the application and refusal of a license, and, if a license has
already been granted, the same shall be forfeited together with all fees paid.
An applicant having been subjected to such penalties may apply within one year
from the date of forfeiture of the license, at the discretion of the Board of
Plumbing Examiners.
(Ord. 20. Passed 3-17-14.)
1446.07 RE-EXAMINATIONS.
   If an applicant fails to pass the requisite examination, he or she may be
re-examined at the next following meeting of the Board of Plumbing Examiners.
If the applicant fails to pass this re-examination, or fails to appear at this
meeting of the Board for re-examination, he or she shall not be re-examined
until the expiration of one year from the last or second examination or the
meeting of the Board at which the applicant failed to appear. At the expiration
of this one-year period, he or she may be re-examined upon filing with the
Board a new application, together with a receipt from the Finance Director
showing that he or she has again paid the fee required by law.
(Ord. 4673. Passed 7-13-94.)
1446.08 RECORDS OF PERSONS EXAMINED.
   The names and standings of all persons examined shall be formally entered on
the records of the Department of Community and Economic Development.
(Ord. 4397. Passed 9-10-86.)
1446.09 APPLICATION FORM.
   The form to be used by a master plumber applying for a certificate of
competency and license shall be substantially as follows:
[Click_here_to_view_application_form_in_PDF_format.]
(Ord. 4673. Passed 7-13-94.)

Ch. 1446
1448.01 LICENSE AND CERTIFICATE REQUIRED.
   No person, other than a registered master plumber, shall carry on or engage
in the business of plumbing or house drainage in the City, and no person shall
expose a sign of plumbing or house drainage, or any advertisement pertaining
thereto, unless he or she has first obtained a license and certificate of
competency therefor and has been registered by the Department of Community and
Economic Development. For all registered plumbers who are doing work within the
City only for house drainage within the City, such individuals may perform
house drainage work within the City without being a master plumber: however,
said individual is required to be registered with the Department of Community
and Economic Development.
(Ord. 4397. Passed 9-10-86; Ord. 5290. Passed 6-10-20.)
1448.02 REGISTRATION OF PERSONS HOLDING LICENSES OR CERTIFICATES FROM OTHER
JURISDICTIONS.
   Any person holding a valid and current license or certificate of competency
granted by any first, second or third class city of the Commonwealth, to engage
in or work at the business of plumbing and drainage work, who desires to do
plumbing or drainage work in the City, may be issued a license or certificate
from the City and before entering upon such work, upon the payment of a fee as
set forth by City Council, which fee shall be paid into the City Treasury. The
registration shall consist of recording such person's name and address only.
However, such registration shall be restricted and limited to such plumbing and
drainage work as such person shall have contracted for at the time of registry.
On the completion of such contract, the registration of such person shall be
null and void and no further permit shall be issued until he or she has first
registered his or her name and address, as provide above in this section.
(Ord. 4397. Passed 9-10-86; Ord. 5290. Passed 6-10-20.)
1448.03 LICENSE AND CERTIFICATE APPLICATIONS; EXAMINATIONS; FEES.
   Every person with three years or more of practical experience who is engaged
in the business or work of plumbing or house and building drainage in the City
shall apply, in writing, to the Bureau of Health for a license and certificate
of competency to do so. If, after proper examination made by the Board of
Plumbing Examiners, such person is found to be competent, that fact shall be
certified to the Codes Administrator who shall thereupon issue a license and
certificate to such person. Such license and certificate shall be valid for one
calendar year or the fractional part thereof next following the date of such
examination and shall entitle such person to engage in or work at the business
of plumbing or house and building drainage. Only one member of a firm or
corporation must hold a master plumbers license. Individuals who do not pass
the examination are thus not qualified to do plumbing work nor drainage work
within the City will be in violation of this chapter.
   The dates for examinations for plumbers licenses shall be fixed and
published by the Board of Plumbing Examiners. The fees for such examinations
shall be as set forth by City Council.
(Ord. 4397. Passed 9-10-86; Ord. 5290. Passed 6-10-20.)
1448.04 RE-REGISTRATION; FEES.
   A re-examination will not be necessary for re-registration, unless the
licensed master or journeyman plumber has failed to make an application for re-
registration at the specified time. The fees for re-registration shall be as
set forth by City Council. The licensed master or journeyman plumber may re-
register by paying the registration fee by March 31 of the current year, and
back the prior two years if outstanding registration fees are owed. All three
years need to be paid in full to place the licensed master or journeyman
plumber in good standing with the City. (Example: By March 31, 2020, the
plumber could pay for year 2020, 2019 & 2018, and will not have to re-test.
However, after that date has passed, the plumber would have to retest for the
plumbing license.)
(Ord. 3795. Passed 12-10-68; Ord. 5290. Passed 6-10-20.)
1448.05 REGISTRY.
   A registration of all master plumbers, journeymen plumbers and apprentices
shall be kept in the Department of Community and Economic Development and shall
be open to the inspection of all persons interested therein.
(Ord. 4397. Passed 9-10-86.)
1448.06 CHANGE OF ADDRESS; RETIREMENT.
   Every registered master plumber shall give immediate notice of any change in
his or her place of business, and upon his or her retirement from business, he
or she shall surrender his or her license and certificate to the Bureau of
Health.
(Ord. 3309. Passed 8-19-58.)
1448.07 PLANS; FEES.
   Any person duly registered as a master plumber who desires to file plans
with the Plumbing Inspector for the installation of plumbing or house drainage
shall, before such plans are approved and a permit is issued, pay to the
Director of Finance fees as set forth by City Council for each plan. However,
where two or more buildings are being built by one owner at the same time on
the same street and between two intersecting streets, a single plan shall be
sufficient, with a fee for each separate unit. Payment of the fee shall be
noted upon the plan.
(Ord. 4673. Passed 7-13-94.)
1448.08 PERFORMANCE OF WORK BY REGISTERED PLUMBERS REQUIRED.
   No person, other than a registered master plumber or a registered journeyman
plumber in his or her employ (registered apprentices excepted), shall install,
alter, repair or make any connection with any drainage pipe, storm pipe
connected to a storm sewer system, medical or industrial gas pipe, soil pipe,
waste pipe, vent pipe or water pipe. For all registered plumbers who are doing
work within the City only for house drainage within the City, such individuals
may perform house drainage work within the City without being a master plumber;
however, said individual must be registered with the Department of Community
and Economic Development.
(Ord. 4850. Passed 3-22-00; Ord. 5290. Passed 6-10-20.)
1448.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

1442.04(b)
1460.01 PERMIT REQUIRED; TIME LIMIT FOR COMPLETION.
   No person shall demolish any structure in the City without first obtaining a
permit therefor. An applicant shall enter into an agreement with the permit
issuing officer on the number of working days which will be permitted to
complete the demolition project for which such permit is being applied for.
Such number of days shall not exceed thirty days from the date of issuance of
such permit.
(Ord. 3687. Passed 6-28-66.)
1460.02 DAILY DISPOSAL OF COMBUSTIBLE MATERIAL.
   No person performing demolition under authority of this chapter shall fail
to carry away all combustible material daily.
(Ord. 3687. Passed 6-28-66.)
1460.03 DISPOSAL OF DEBRIS.
   No person performing demolition under authority of this chapter shall fail
to carry away all debris not to be used as backfill.
(Ord. 3687. Passed 6-28-66.)
1460.04 FILLING AND GRADING.
   No person performing demolition under authority of this chapter shall fail
to raze all foundation walls above ground, fill the basement with solid
materials and grade to the level of the immediately surrounding area.
(Ord. 3687. Passed 6-28-66.)
1460.05 PROTECTION OF PUBLIC AND STRUCTURES.
   No person performing demolition under authority of this chapter shall fail
to take every necessary precaution to protect the traveling public and adjacent
structures.
(Ord. 3687. Passed 6-28-66.)
1460.06 REMOVAL OF UTILITY CONNECTIONS; SEALING OF SEWER OPENINGS.
   No person performing demolition under authority of this chapter shall fail
to make the necessary arrangements for the elimination of all utility
connections which exist on the premises at the time of such demolition, in the
usual and proper manner. Such person shall also seal all sewer openings.
(Ord. 3687. Passed 6-28-66.)
1460.07 INSURANCE.
   A person performing demolition within the City shall carry public liability
insurance in the amounts of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) and three
hundred thousand dollars ($300,000) for personal injury, and twenty-five
thousand dollars ($25,000) property damage. A certificate evidencing the same
shall be exhibited to the permit issuing officer of the City upon demand.
However, the permit issuing officer may require, at his or her discretion,
insurance on a sliding scale up to the maximum amount of three hundred thousand
dollars ($300,000) and six hundred thousand dollars ($600,000) for personal
injury, and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) for property damage,
depending upon the danger to be alleviated and the presence of probable injury
to individuals surrounding such work.
(Ord. 3700. Passed 9-20-66.)
1460.08 PAYMENT OF COSTS.
   No person performing demolition under authority of this chapter shall fail
to secure and pay for all permits, fees, costs and charges incidental to such
demolition.
(Ord. 3687. Passed 6-28-66.)
1460.09 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED; WORKER'S COMPENSATION AND UNEMPLOYMENT INSURANCE.
   No person performing demolition under authority of this chapter shall fail
to abide by all City ordinances and laws of the Commonwealth governing
demolition work. Every such person shall also carry worker's compensation
insurance and unemployment insurance and must comply with the Pennsylvania
Minimum Wage Law.
(Ord. 3687. Passed 6-28-66.)
1460.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
